organization.name: OpenRank
organization.description: OpenRank is a decentralized ranking and reputation protocol. It enables a verifiable reputation compute layer for the open web that unlocks a broad range of useful applications, including those that resist cryptographic or game-theoretic mechanisms of trust. Using graph compute algorithms like EigenTrust, it offers resilience from sybil contexts, provides scalable and context-specific compute, and enables permissionless access to compute and reputation data for any developer.

name: Retro 5 Expert Voter Selection: Developer Reputation Score using Recursive Trust
description:
[WHAT WE DID]

Guest voter selection for Retro 5, was based on software development expertise evident by a developer's Github user reputation score, under the guidance of Optimism Citizens House. The developer reputation scores are based on calculating recursive trust across the Github developer activity graph. This ranking is seeded by OP Stack repos. This means Github repos and developers 

This was an important experiment because certain retro funding rounds, such as this round, has particular expertise involved in assessing and judging the quality and impact of the applicant projects. In the case of Retro 5, the applicants are repos to OP Stack, therefore it makes sense to select top contributing and highly reputable developers as guest voters, so that the collective governance can benefit from their technical and topical expertise. are scored based on recursive trust signals, originating from these seed trust repos. https://gov.optimism.io/t/retro-funding-5-expert-voting-experiment/8613

More on our effort into applying the algorithm in custom context, pre and post processing the data, and iterations: https://gov.optimism.io/t/retro-funding-5-guest-voter-selection-algorithm-explanation/8719

[OUR IMPACT] 

30 top contributors to OP stack were identified and selected as expert voters for Retro 5 round - OP Stack.

74K+ Github developers were given a reputation score seeded to indicate their contribution, taken into consideration the quality of their code contribution, to Optimism core repo stacks. And the score results are readily available for any Optimism ecosystem projects to use.

[WHAT IS OpenRank]

name: Self-Serve Developer Ranking platform
description:
[WHAT WE DID]

This web app https://devrankings.openrank.com/ enables any community or project to create your own Developer and Github repository rankings, using Github developer activity graph. The GitHub data is public from by Open Source Observer. The ranking and reputation compute is permissionless and verifiable, powered by OpenRank Protocol. Communities can leverage this tool to generate developer and repo reputation scores given their own seed trust. 

This tool helps everyone to have a quick understanding of how the developer and repo reputation scores are generated, through the step-by-step process of selecting ranking criteria, seed trust peers, and strength of seed trust peers‚Äô opinion influencing the reputation score of the rest of the peers. 

[OUR IMPACT]

The web app is powered by a graph of relevant GitHub event data from Open Source Observer, covering more than 2,000 organizations and over 30,000 code repositories, was employed in generating these scores. We established two kinds of peers: GitHub users and repositories. We then used a variation of EigenTrust, the Hubs and Authorities algorithm, which computes rankings on an asymmetric bipartite trust graph. 

The web app made it possible to generate client-side compute results, and replicate the same computation used in Retro 5, therefore it also serves as an educational and accountability tool for Optimism collective to better understand the governance metrics and algos used in a verifiable and transparent way.

name: Snapshot
description:
Snapshot started as a voting platform designed to allow onchain organizations to vote easily without gas fees. Its strength lies in its flexibility and high customization, catering to the diverse needs of its users. This includes options for calculating users' voting power, selecting different voting mechanisms, and managing proposal and vote validation rules.

As the gas cost dropped with the maturity of L2s and the need for more decentralized and trustless voting grew, we developed Snapshot X, an onchain voting protocol. Unlike the original Snapshot, Snapshot X operates fully onchain using a set of modular smart contracts. This shift makes Snapshot censorship resistant, with onchain and cross-chain voting power computation and trustless execution, while keeping gas costs to the minimal extent possible.

statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
In addition to the Citizens' House, many organizations across the Optimism and Base ecosystems have adopted Snapshot for governance. During period counting for RPGF6, on Optimism, Snapshot supported 1,085 active spaces, enabling 3,565 proposals and facilitating over 7.5 million votes from 934,550 active voters. On Base, Snapshot supported 262 spaces with 1,288 proposals, resulting in 62,475 votes from 19,591 voters. This widespread adoption positions Snapshot as the leading governance platform with the most impact within the Superchain ecosystem.

With the launch of Snapshot X, our onchain governance framework, we expect many of these users to transition from offchain to onchain voting. In particular, those using voting power from OP or Base are likely to vote on these chains, significantly increasing onchain governance activity, directly benefiting the entire Optimism Collective.

organization.name: Open Source Observer
organization.description: Open Source Observer is a free analytics suite that helps the Optimism Collective measure the impact of open source software contributions on the growth of the Superchain. We provide foundational datasets and metrics models as a public good and use these to derive insights for improving Retro Funding and grant effectiveness. Our code and infrastructure are fully open source, enabling anyone to audit or fork our models. We also lead a growing data science community motivated by the vision of "impact = profit."

name: OSO Insights & Data Science
description:
Open Source Observer is a public good that helps communities measure impact and improve grant effectiveness. Alongside our work providing impact metrics for specific funding rounds, we also employ data science to evaluate the long-term efficacy of Retro Funding as a mechanism and conduct robust analyses to ensure the integrity of each funding round.

We help the Optimism Collective analyze voter behavior and reward distribution patterns, project/contribution reputation, and the performance of cohorts of projects over time. These efforts are intended to provide the community with a more nuanced understanding of each round's effectiveness and inform future round designs.

In addition, we conduct ad hoc analyses to verify results calculations, screen projects for eligibility requirements, and create synthetic data for testing purposes. This work is high-context and requires a deep understanding of each round's design parameters, voters, and project pools.

Our insights leverage both our OSO data pipeline and a variety of partner data sources, including Farcaster, OpenRank, Agora, Ethereum Attestation Service, and others. All of our work is public and intended to be easily reproducible by the community.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

statement.answer:
Our work is primarily focused on analyzing grant allocations and the participation / revealed preferences of badgeholders during Retro Funding voting.

For instance, after each round during the current period (ie, RF3 and RF4), we authored an "Opening up the ballot box" piece, looking in detail at various voter patterns, biases, and clustering effects. 

Another example is our "longitudinal analysis" piece, which looks at distinct cohorts of Retro Funding projects over time and identifies patterns related to grant allocation and project growth / momentum. 

In addition to these retrospective pieces, we also assist Optimism Governance (and partners) to simulate voter behaviors and biases when designing rounds and voting interfaces.
statement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?

statement.answer:
The reality is that most of our insights are targeted at governance nerds: the most active/engaged  badgeholders, the Foundation, and a subset of Token House members who are active on the governance forum.

Our ideas have been quoted in round design specs (see [here](https://gov.optimism.io/t/upcoming-retro-rounds-and-their-design/7861)) as well as in good-natured debate about the efficacy of grant allocation results (see [here](https://gov.optimism.io/t/new-rpgf3-distribution-disparity-data/7521)). 

Our post on the [300+ OSS projects applying for RF3](https://gov.optimism.io/t/analysis-on-the-300-oss-projects-applying-for-retropgf-3/7127) received 90+ likes on the governance forum, putting it in [the top 5](https://gov.optimism.io/top?period=yearly) of all posts over the period.

statement.answer:
We have created a comprehensive analysis of Optimism Badgeholder's onchain activity vs a control group of active non-Badgeholders. In particular, we looked at transaction activity across chains, involvement in social apps (Farcaster, Lens, Friendtech), participation in other DAOs (Arbitrum, Uniswap, ENS) and the deployment of smart contracts and NFTs. 

Something to note: although it is true that not all citizens use their Badgeholder address for other onchain activity, we found that a significant amount did and we discuss the implications of this constraint in the report.
statement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?

statement.answer:
The Optimism Foundation. This work was requested directly by the Foundation in order to get a better understanding of Optimism Badgeholders vs ‚Äúnormal‚Äù Ethereum users. In their own words: ‚ÄúIn order to confidently expand the Citizenry, we need to have a baseline understanding of the current Badgeholder group. Our goal is to get a better understanding of the Badgeholder group based on their onchain activity compared with the onchain activity of other active Optimism/Ethereum users.‚Äù

In addition, the entire Optimism Collective has benefitted from the transparency provided by this publicly available work. It's open source nature sets the stage for others to conduct further research and expand upon our results.

links.name: Optimism Cycle 19
links.description:
Cantina contributed to the security and robustness of Optimism Governance infrastructure through a comprehensive security audit of Optimism during Cycle 19. This audit reviewed critical components such as the ERC721Bridge contract and OptimismPortal. The audit identified a total of 14 issues, including 7 low-risk findings and 7 informational findings. These findings were essential for ensuring the long-term resilience and safety of Optimism's governance infrastructure, including addressing deployment compatibility with MCP L1 and improving security practices within governance-related contracts. This security audit improved the integrity of governance tooling by identifying potential vulnerabilities and inconsistencies, ultimately helping secure the governance process.

Key Audit Results:

Critical, High, and Medium Risks: None identified.
Low-Risk Issues: 7 found, all acknowledged but not yet fixed.
Informational Issues: 7 found, all acknowledged but not yet fixed.
Gas Optimization Issues: None identified.

name: numbaNERDs
description:
The numbaNERDs Program is a governance-focused bounty board that delivers key analytics on grant recipients and their performance. Run by an Alliance of OP Labs employees, the program incentivizes contributors to generate insights that drive informed governance decisions.

Some bounties are reserved for previous contributors, known as numbaNERDs, allowing experienced individuals to provide in-depth analysis. A grants misuse reporting policy is also in place, where anyone can report misuse, but only numbaNERDs contributors can validate these reports. The policy outlines violations with varying severity, ensuring that any protocol misuse is addressed with appropriate consequences, while encouraging protocols to avoid misuse. 

Through its structured analytics and accountability measures, the numbaNERDs Program strengthens transparency and governance in the Optimism ecosystem.

organization.name: Giveth
organization.description:
Giveth is an open-source, radically transparent, user-friendly donation platform that supports verified public goods projects to raise crypto with zero added fees and no intermediaries. We build and advance novel fundraising mechanisms like quadratic funding, donor rewards, and decentralized project curation.

## Giveth supports P2P donations on Optimism and Base.  

Giveth has been live on Optimism since 2023, enabling projects to accept Optimism donations (approx. $330k USD raised by hundreds of projects on OP Mainnet as of June 5, 2024). Donations on Giveth are truly P2P without even contracts in the middle, so the donations we facilitate in the platform can't be included in our metrics in this application.

Through our GIVbacks program, we reward donors to verified projects with GIV on Optimism, having distributed  6.64 million GIV on OP Mainnet (from launch to June 11, 2024).  

As an additional onboarding effort for high-trust community members, we have been offering 25 OP to each project on Giveth who passes our verification system requirements, and adds an Optimism recipient address (296 projects onboarded so far). 

To enhance these onboarding efforts, we have been running quadratic funding rounds that require verified projects to add an Optimism address, with matching pools on Optimism so far totaling approximately $83,000. 

## How it works

Giveth goes beyond ‚Äújust donations‚Äù with the following features:

* GIVbacks - Donors who give to verified public goods projects get rewarded with GIV on OP Mainnet. This flips the script on tax-deductible donation, creating a decentralized and borderless way of incentivizing donations.
* GIVpower - Users can lock their GIV tokens on OP Mainnet to earn a yield and get GIVpower. People can use GIVpower to boost/curate projects on the platform. Projects with more GIVpower are ranked higher, and in turn, their donors are rewarded with more GIVbacks, similar to the veToken model. Top-boosted projects also appear higher on Giveth!
* Quadratic Funding - The democratic matching program popularized by Gitcoin is also available on Giveth! Projects and donors enjoy multi-chain donation rounds with an easy and streamlined user experience.

## Who uses it

Currently, over 3,400 projects have raised $2.8m from 58,600+ donations from over 16,600 donor addresses on Giveth. 

To understand how deep our link with the Optimism ecosystem is, if we consider only Optimism numbers, we have 799 projects, 4012 donors, 17,500+ donations, and $329k+.

Projects that want to get to the next level can apply to be ‚ÄúVerified‚Äù as a public goods creator, providing information about their impact history and reputation at stake.

Giveth is onboarding real-world impact projects to web3 by empowering them with free access to novel fundraising mechanisms and new ecosystems of donors, while inspiring them to dive deeper down the blockchain rabbit hole.

So far in 2024, we have made HUGE progress, running four quadratic funding rounds supporting donations on Optimism with the following results:

Total in matching pools: $107,563
Individual donations: $65,500
Projects participating: 249 
Unique donors: 1914
Donations: 1433

Giving Season Round  (December 19, 2023 - January 2, 2024)
https://forum.giveth.io/t/qf-giving-season-round-results-december-19-2023-january-2-2024/1305

MetaPool APAC Round (February 19-29, 2024)
https://forum.giveth.io/t/meta-pool-apac-qf-round-results-feb-19-29-2024/1358

ENS Builders Round (March 25-April 8, 2024)
https://forum.giveth.io/t/ens-builders-qf-round-march-25-april-8-2024/1410

Galactic Giving Round (May 2-16, 2024)
https://forum.giveth.io/t/galactic-giving-round-results-may-2-16-2024/1445

We also launched loads of features including a custom donation widget, a project curation program, and streaming donations.

We sincerely thank the Optimistic community for allowing us to participate and build in such a fantastic ecosystem.

name: DeVouch powered by Giveth
description:
Giveth is an open-source, radically transparent, user-friendly donation platform that supports and verifies public goods projects, enabling them to raise crypto with zero added fees and no intermediaries. Today, Giveth supports donations on OP Mainnet, Ethereum Mainnet, Base, Celo, as well as 7 other chains, and several OP Governance projects, such as growthepie, DAOstar, Pairwise, Praise & EAS raise funds on our platform.

Recently, in coordination with the Optimism Token House, we launched DeVouch, a system for members of reputable organizations in the Ethereum ecosystem to vouch for projects looking to raise funding. It was created with special attention to the Optimism Retro Funding mechanism.

How does it work?

By vouching for a project, the organization can lend its credibility to the project, building confidence for those looking to support it with funding.

DeVouch collects projects from Gitcoin, Giveth, and Optimism Retro Funding rounds and showcases them in a single place, allowing all users to either vouch for or flag each project. Visitors to the website can see the vouches and flags received by each project, which were tracked by the "Attester Group" that the vouch or flag came from. 

Attester Groups are formed by looking at on-chain Attestation Data from EAS on Optimism to know who belongs to which organization or community sub-set by which Attestations have been issued to them and by whom. An example of Attester Groups are RetroFunding 5 voters or Gitcoin passport holders.

This allows members of these groups to lend their reputation to the project looking for funding. However, attesting with DeVouch is a double-edged sword, if a project seems suspicious or untrustworthy then they could also receive a flag, warning others to think twice before supporting this project.

DeVouch is open-source and allows any platform or individual to query DeVouch data using our graphQL API as well as contribute by the issuance of attestations using the DeVouch schema. Anyone can also add their Attester Group to DeVouch by making a simple PR on the DeVouch Github Repository

Who uses it?

DeVouch was launched in early June 2024, and has been featured as additional tooling in Retro Funding 5. Giveth is also integrating it to provide Decentralized Verification of projects seeking funding on the platform.

Considering that we launched on June 12th of this year, the over 700 onchain attestations that‚Äôve happened through DeVouch before September 18th shows that there are good expectations, regarding the growth of users.

Also, to map potential, we look at the demand for such a service, and specifically with Optimism, we have over 591 projects (according to Alchemy) between dApps, dexes, etc., which are all looking to take fundraising opportunities and a piece of the $3.3B in Public Goods funding that was set aside by the Optimism Collective. 

A decentralized vouching system is essential to bringing more efficiency to allocating funds, as well as to map the reputation of each project by the entire Optimism Community. Is a project a scam? Flag it! Is a project legit? Vouch for it!

Giveth is known for its ability to support projects in their fundraising effort, and yes from October 2023 until September 18th 2024 we facilitated nearly $1M of donations to projects on our platform, and rewarded donors via our GIVbacks program. But our efforts to verify projects are legitimate is often forgotten. With DeVouch, we are decentralizing this effort and enabling other programs, especially in the Superchain, to also verify that the projects applying for funding are legitimate.

statement.answer:
Since Giveth‚Äôs launch of DeVouch in June until Sep 18th, there were over 700 attestations made, with over 150 being for projects in Retro Funding 4 & 5. Our modular tool allows anyone to lend their credibility to projects that are applying for RetroFunding rounds, as well as fundraising on Gitcoin & Giveth. 

DeVouch is built in a modular way that allows any grant program to add their projects & any attestor groups to add their reputation. Our default UI allows badgeholders to see in a glance how many people of relevant reputation vouch for the project; e.g. you can quickly see that 2 RF4 Badgeholders, 3 OP Delegates, 11 Gitcoin Passport Holders, 1 RF5 Voter, & 1 Giveth Verifier all [vouched for EAS](https://devouch.xyz/?source=rf5).

Every project that applied to RF4 & RF5, even those that were rejected, were able to be vouched for, or flagged during the review period. Many of the rejected projects were accurately flagged by the community on DeVouch.
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
The OP community (esp. delegates) can support projects that are adding value to the Superchain Community. While unable to participate in Retro Funding directly, through DeVouch, they can lend their credibility to them, and leave a comment about the project using our extremely easy to use UX. [Try it out!](https://devouch.xyz/?source=rf6)

Voters & reviewers in Retro Funding programs are able to incorporate the wisdom of the crowds. 

We helped the Foundation prevent imposters. DeVouch made tweets tagging every project that applied in RF5. If impersonation occurred, the project would have seen the tweet, flagged it on DeVouch and reported it.

Projects have a simple way to prove their legitimacy in an industry ripe with scams. Giveth also ran 9 QF rounds (7 hosted on Superchain networks), raising over [$865k for projects](https://giveth.io/qf-archive) like EAS, Pairwise & growthepie alongside projects that are making irl impact like Palestine Children's Relief Fund or the EFF.

name: GovGraph.fyi
description:
GovGraph is an innovative approach to visualizing and understanding the relationships within governance ecosystems. Unlike traditional scoring systems, GovGraph focuses on the connections and interactions between power users, such as Delegates, Developers, and Citizens. 

By mapping these relationships through a dynamic and interactive graph, users can identify alliances, conflicts of interest, and clusters of influence. The system allows for detailed filtering and searching, providing insights into social graphs, voting patterns, and potential sybil attacks. This project aims to enhance the transparency and efficiency of the governance and funding processes.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

statement.answer:
Now we‚Äôve analyzed ~200 OP citizens (delegates and projects data is being processed now as well), and their connections over 10 data sources (Farcaster, on-chain attestations, token holdings and community association, more: https://govgraph.fyi/connection-types). The intention was to understand the nature of relations inside of the house, identify the centers of influence, and support matchmaking for the alliances. We‚Äôve identified 9 other potential use cases for the tool: https://govgraph.fyi/use-cases.

Some Insight from the current study:
- lindaxie.eth (followed by 88 citizens), w.jesse.xyz (86), purple.philm.eth (75), 0x91...5871 (75), vitalik.eth (74) are the most followed accounts on Farcaster
- Only 19 people (~10%) have no identified connections
- Potential connections within the Regen movement ‚Äì 49 people (~25%)

This work led us also to explore the Sybil algorithms for the Farcaster, where we can reuse some data and insights already.

name: Optimism Developer Advisory Board (S6)
description:
The Developer Advisory Board (DAB) brings a technical perspective to everything that happens in Optimism governance. 

Running the Collective requires a lot of important technical decision making:
- Which upgrades are safe? 
- Which projects are making a meaningful technical impact? 
- Which grants deserve to be funded?

The DAB works to ensure these decisions are made correctly. Our responsibilities include supporting Grants Council with technical assessments of projects, supporting citizens and delegates with simple protocol upgrade explanations, and being a nexus for communication between OP Labs, the Foundation, delegates, citizens, developers, and other stakeholders.

statement.question: In what season did your work take place

statement.answer:
The Developer Advisory Board (DAB) was reelected in Season 6. [Our charter can be found in the initial budget proposal](https://gov.optimism.io/t/zach-obront-developer-advisory-board-operating-budget/8141), and includes supporting the Optimism ecosystem as follows:

1. Help to ensure the safety of protocol upgrades. We do this by both (a) explicitly approving upgrades before they are allowed to move to a vote and (b) providing plain English summaries of all protocol upgrades to educate other voters.

2. Support the Grants Council by providing detailed technical feedback on all Mission Requests, Mission Applications, and grant milestones.

3. Bring an additional technical perspective to thinking about the vision of the OP ecosystem and what needs to happen to get there.

More details can be found in our [Internal Operating Procedures](https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board-s6-internal-operating-procedures/8558).

The GC Lead has provided an NPS score of 10/10 based on the value of our contributions.

name: OP Passport
description:
OP Passport is a tool that provides users with an on-chain identity to track and showcase their governance participation within the Optimism Collective. In decentralized governance, it can be difficult to verify contributions, voting history, and achievements in a transparent and secure way.

OP Passport addresses this challenge by serving as a digital identity that securely stores  your governance activities achievements through on-chain attestations in your smart wallet. It allows participants to demonstrate their active involvement in governance, making it easier for the community to recognize valuable contributors. The platform also enables on-chain endorsements, both public and anonymous, further enhancing transparency and accountability within the governance process.

statement.answer:
OP Passport supports Optimism Governance by providing users with a verifiable, on-chain identity to track and showcase their governance participation. In decentralized governance, it is often difficult to transparently display contributions, voting history, and achievements. OP Passport addresses this challenge by securely storing governance activities and accomplishments through on-chain attestations within users‚Äô smart wallets.

The tool enables participants to easily demonstrate their active involvement in governance, making it simpler for the community to recognize valuable contributors. Additionally, OP Passport facilitates on-chain endorsements, both public and anonymous, which further enhance transparency and accountability across the governance process.
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
OP Passport benefits three key governance participants within the Optimism Collective: delegates, delegators, and badgeholders, all of whom can create their own passports, earn achievements, and give or receive endorsements.

Delegates: OP Passport allows delegates to create an on-chain record of their achievements, showcasing their profile to build trust and increase recognition of their contributions.

Delegators: Delegators can track their delegates' actions and assess how their voting power is used. They can also give and receive endorsements, promoting transparency and accountability.

Badgeholders: Badgeholders can earn achievements and give or receive endorsements, recognizing valuable contributions and fostering transparency in governance.

Through OP Passport, all participants can create passports, earn achievements, and showcase their governance contributions, strengthening transparency and accountability in the Optimism ecosystem.

name: RetroList
description:
RetroList is a project discovery platform for Retro Funding, covering rounds 3 to 6 of OP Retro Funding.

RetroList also offers detailed analytics for each round, including:
- Project reward distribution across different reward groups
- Project reward distribution by category
- Public crowdsourcing lists for RetroPGF 3
- Metrics distribution for Retro Funding 4
- Open-source vs. closed-source project distribution for Retro Funding 4
- Project reward breakdown by impact metrics for Retro Funding 4

Additionally, RetroList provides an API for projects to query data. Our API is typically launched a few days after the signup period and maintains a stable schema.

The RetroList API is currently used by DeVouch and Impact Garden.

For more information about the RetroList API, please contact @chomtana on Telegram.

name: Impact Calculator Prototype
description:

This build demonstrated the potential of this approach while also raising awareness of pitfalls. 

We worked closely with Jonas of the Optimism Foundation to try different solutions and work through challenges as they arose. 

Jonas can be quoted with the following statement in regards to this contribution:
"The Impact Calculator tool played a crucial role in experimenting with metrics-based voting, significantly shaping the design of Retro Funding 4. By providing practical insights into the implementation of metrics-based voting, it accelerated the development process and contributed to a more effective and informed design."

organization.name: Token Engineering Academy (TE Academy)
organization.description:
Rooted in the Optimism Ecosystem, Token Engineering Academy (TE Academy) provides applied research and education to ‚àº5K professionals and students covering mechanism design, token-based governance, tokenomics, and more. TE Academy‚Äôs mission is to establish rigorous design, verification, and optimization of token-based systems. We call this token engineering, a new crypto-native engineering field.

Our educational activities include online courses like Token Engineering Fundamentals, cohort-based programs like the 2024 Study Season Program, and workshops and programs at conferences such as EthCC and Devconnect Istanbul. All of our educational programs are provided as public goods, with no fees for students. 
TE Fundamentals: https://tokenengineering.net/
2024 Study Season Program: https://te-academy.notion.site/Welcome-to-TE-Academy-s-Study-Season-Information-Hub-dde8cebd28344071acffa4cf3d195c01

TE Academy‚Äôs services include mechanism design and incentive strategies for crypto protocols and Dapps. We draw from scientific fields such as game theory, systems engineering, and social choice theory. We apply theoretical analysis, modeling, and simulations, as well as machine learning and AI.

Our global network includes top cryptoeconomics researchers (e.g., GovXS, BlockScience, Gauntlet, Ethereum Foundation, Metagov) and tokenomics practitioners (e.g., 1kx, Messari, Tokenomia.pro, etc.) 
Our partners include Optimism, Gnosis, Carbon DeFi, Ocean Protocol, Consensys, Balancer, ENS DAO, 1kx, Outlier Ventures, and more.

We invest in finding and supporting young talents via our online educational program with students enrolled from all over the world, in addition to our Fellowship Prize that awards the most relevant work in our field with visibility and a cash prize.

Token Engineering Academy is a proud recipient of  Retro Funding in round 2 and round 3, and we remain proud to re-invest these funds to equip the Optimism community with the education and expertise needed to drive the long-term success of the Superchain.

name: GovXS
description:
GovXS is an initiative under Token Engineering Academy, which is a proud recipient of Optimism RetroPGF funding in Rounds 2 and 3. 

GovXS was selected to complete the Optimism Foundation‚Äôs Mission Request #188‚ÄìEvaluating Voting Design Tradeoffs for Retro Funding in June 2024. Our team of 4 experts in social choice theory, modeling and simulations, and token engineering (Nimrod Talmon, PhD, Angela Kreitenweis, Eyal Briman, and Muhammad Idrees) has now gone beyond the Mission Request‚Äôs scope to analyze actual Optimism Retro Funding voting designs and improve governance performance by proposing new, strategyproof voting rules.

**Deliverables by September 18:**

- Voting Design Mathematical Specification:
Deriving the formal specification of the exact voting rules applied in Optimism‚Äôs Retro Funding Rounds 1‚Äì4 (R1‚Äì4) to allow for rigorous, axiomatic analysis

- Voting Design Evaluation Framework:
Deriving a 360¬∞ evaluation framework based on Optimism Retro Funding objectives

- Voting Design Evaluation Metrics:
Developing metrics to rigorously verify voting designs against Retro Funding objectives, applying theoretical, axiomatic analysis and agent-based simulations 

- Testing and Verification of Optimism‚Äôs R1‚Äì4 Voting Rules:
Verifying if the R1‚Äì4 voting rules satisfy Incentive Compatibility so that voters can not improve their results by lying about their preferences (known as ‚Äústrategyproofness‚Äù in social choice theory)

- Detection of Major Flaws in Optimism Retro Funding:
We found major flaws in the Optimism Retro Funding voting designs (none of the R1‚Äì4 voting designs satisfy strategyproofness!)

- Provided 2 Strategyproof Solutions:
GovXS proposed two alternative voting designs to solve strategyproofness and meet Optimism Retro Funding‚Äôs design goals 

** Links:** 
1) Making Optimism Retro Funding Strategyproof (Report) ‚Äì https://mirror.xyz/0x803860D2C333734cD99625d8d189d0Eb2e565166/gvjQpafjVxAeeQnb7_Oc--5Oc7chV55zwR_NCa1_9KU

2) A Social Choice Analysis of Retroactive Funding (PDF) ‚Äì https://github.com/GovXS/Evaluating-Voting-Design-Tradeoffs-for-Retro-Funding/blob/main/A%20Social%20Choice%20Analysis%20of%20Retroactive%20Funding.pdf

3) GovXS Retro Funding Simulator (Open-source) ‚Äì¬†https://github.com/GovXS/Evaluating-Voting-Design-Tradeoffs-for-Retro-Funding


**Positive impact:**

- Securing Truthful Voting:
Using strategyproof voting designs ensures that voters can achieve their best results only by voting according to their true preferences. Current Retro Funding voting designs are not strategyproof. We propose alternative voting designs to solve this issue.

- Securing Expert/Guest Voter Experiments:
Optimism Retro Funding is running experiments with badgeholders, guest voters, and expert voters, investing sizably to gain insights on how to best select the most knowledgeable, value-aligned voters. These insights rely on learnings from analyzing voting data and voter preferences. If this data is skewed due to voting designs not being strategyproof, wrong conclusions will be drawn, creating negative impacts e.g. on future rounds‚Äô scope and size, or voter and project participation, hurting the entire ecosystem.

- Securing ‚ÄúImpact = Profit‚Äù:
Optimism's vision is to build a global system where positive impact to the collective is rewarded by profit to the individual, so that ‚ÄúImpact = Profit‚Äù. Retro Funding aims to find the ground truth in funding allocation. There is no instrument or algorithm yet to measure a project‚Äôs positive impact and the respective profit it deserves. That‚Äôs why you, as a voter, are asked to assess project applications by voting in Retro Funding. If the voting rule provides voters with the wrong incentives, the results will be distorted, and Optimism Retro Funding cannot get any closer to reaching a fair, objective truth supporting ‚ÄúImpact = Profit‚Äù.

statement.answer:
GovXS analyzed the voting designs used in Optimism Retro Funding across Rounds 1‚Äì4, focusing on whether voters were incentivized to truthfully report their preferences. Our analysis uncovered a critical flaw: none of the voting rules applied so far are strategyproof! 
In other words, voters can gain an advantage by not voting according to their true preferences. To fix this, we proposed two alternative voting solutions, along with clear, actionable recommendations for their implementation.
statement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?

statement.answer:
a) **Optimism Retro Funding Program:** GovXS‚Äôs advanced analytics have empowered the OP Retro Funding Program to identify and solve critical flaws and enable a strategyproof voting that upholds the integrity of retro funding.
b) **Optimism Retro Funding badgeholders, experts, and guest voters:** Badgeholders, experts and guest voters gain trust that voting outcomes reflect the true preferences of all participants.
c) **Optimism Retro Funding projects:** With GovXS‚Äôs analytics-driven recommendations, Optimism Retro Funding projects have confidence in a voting process that guarantees fair compensation through transparent, objective assessments.
d) **Superchain Ecosystem:** Optimism‚Äôs Retro Funding strives to achieve a true, fair allocation of rewards. Flawed voting rules distort outcomes, preventing Optimism Retro Funding from realizing its goal of aligning 'Impact = Profit.' GovXs‚Äôs analysis provided actionable solutions to safeguard this vision for the long term.

statement.answer:
The mandate of the Token House Collective Feedback Commission (CFC) is to formalize the process of gathering high-context feedback from engaged community members during the design phase, rather than after designs are finalized. By consulting the Foundation on early-stage drafts, we ensure that input from top delegates and governance leads directly shapes decisions as they are being developed. CFC members provided feedback on any drafts shared by the Optimism Foundation. This approach marks a significant first step toward deeper community involvement in the governance design process, aligning with the long-term goal of increased community ownership. 

More details can be found here:
- Introducing the Collective Feedback Commission
https://gov.optimism.io/t/introducing-the-collective-feedback-commission/7863
- The Path to Open Metagovernance
https://gov.optimism.io/t/the-path-to-open-metagovernance/7728

Key impacts include:

- Implemented a 72-hour response SLA for the Developer Advisory Board (DAB).
- Clarified retro reward eligibility and expanded ‚Äústakeholders‚Äù scope.
- Strengthened Chain Delegation Program with clearer criteria.
- Refined the Superchain strategy, leading to the Vision AMA.

Based on this success, the Commission will continue into its next iteration. More details here:

name: Syntra
description:
Syntra is a delegate dashboard that simplifies DAO governance by streamlining drafting, decision-making, and management with calendar integration.

In the evolving world of decentralized governance, DAOs have become central to decision-making across Web3. Yet, for many delegates, the tools and processes available often feel fragmented, isolated, and hard to navigate. We‚Äôve experienced these challenges firsthand, not just as developers but as participants in various DAOs.

Syntra is a delegate dashboard born from this realization: governance doesn‚Äôt need an isolated tool‚Äîit requires an integrated solution focused on people, the ones driving these organizations forward.

Shift in Focus: From Tools to People

For too long, DAO tooling has been focused on solving specific issues‚Äîone tool for proposals, another for voting, and yet another for analytics. The result? A fragmented experience that leaves participants, both newcomers and experienced teams, struggling to piece together a coherent workflow.

Our Approach

We knew there had to be a better way, so we asked: What if we could give DAO participants a head start? What if we could streamline these processes, so they can focus on what really matters‚Äîmaking impactful decisions?. Our target user base varies from newcomers to professional delegates leading teams of 10+ members.

For newcomers: Syntra lowers the barriers to entry, making it easier to draft proposals, post comments, participate in discussions, vote, and analyze governance activity.
For professional organizations: It facilitates coordination and collaboration, providing role-based access and tracking tools to streamline internal processes.
By integrating many of the existing tools within the DAO ecosystem, we help delegates manage governance processes more efficiently, improving not just individual contributions but also team-based workflows.

organization.description: OpenRank is a decentralized ranking and reputation protocol. It enables a verifiable reputation compute layer for the open web that unlocks a broad range of useful applications, including those that resist cryptographic or game-theoretic mechanisms of trust. name: Retro 5 Metrics: Trusted Github Contributors/Stars/Forks
description:
[What WE DID]

5 impact metrics were introduced in Retro 5 to give additional information on the repo reputation, or quality indication for voters to make informed decisions. We used the same algorithm used for guest voter selection, but utilize the scores differently to create repo reputations. For example, instead of number of forks, voters can see the number of forks by reputable developers, and they can see the weighted and aggregated reputation scores of all developers who forked this repo. https://gov.optimism.io/t/impact-metrics-for-retro-funding-5/8931
TL;DR 1min video walk through: https://www.loom.com/share/92ccf283b670477d9bf147f8b66a22e3?sid=9fcf321f-8dd3-4ba7-8221-8a301b9b15d3

[OUR IMPACT] 

Now we have reputation scores for 47K repos in Github for their contribution to OP Stack core repos. And these scores are readily available for any developer in OP ecosystem to use.

Introducing reputation metrics is important because 1) voters need better signals to know if a repo is contributing to OP stack and to what degree is that contribution; 2) voters need signals to know if a repo has been interacted by reputable developers, which adds to an underlying endorsement of the value of the repos. 

More on our work: https://x.com/SahilDewan/status/1839701853258530864

[WHAT IS OpenRank]

OpenRank is a decentralized ranking and reputation protocol. It enables a verifiable reputation compute layer for the open web that unlocks a broad range of useful applications, including those that resist cryptographic or game-theoretic mechanisms of trust. Using graph compute algorithms like EigenTrust, it offers resilience from sybil contexts, provides scalable and context-specific compute, and enables permissionless access to compute and reputation data for any user.

We made possible 5 impact metrics in Retro 5 to give additional information on the repo reputation, or quality indication for voters to make informed decisions.

Using a web-of-trust approach, the metrics were generated from a reputation graph created on Github activities. These metrics are trust-weighted, and have served voters in Retro round 5 to better understand the quality and reputation of a given repo, beyond just traditional stars/forks/contributors numbers, which are not Sybil-resistant.

name: DeepDAO
description:
DeepDAO aggregates comprehensive data on the Optimism Collective, as well as 296 other DAOs on optimism mainnet. Our industry-leading dashboard surfaces insights on: 

- OP Collective‚Äôs DAO treasury (including treasury assets, trends, and contracts), 
- OP Collective‚Äôs governance (including various voter and proposal activity metrics and trends), 
- OP Collective‚Äôs delegation ecosystem (including top active delegates and badgeholders),
- OP Collective‚Äôs governance centralization through coalitions analysis,
- OP Collective‚Äôs governance resilience by analyzing the impact of token price on governance. 
- OP Collective‚Äôs voter participation in other DAOs, enabling marketing insights, and voter groups such as loyal voters, missing voters.

DeepDAO dashboards have been live for over 4 years, and we have been providing comprehensive and free-to-access DAO data to all participants in the OP Collective from day one. DeepDAO data is widely used in academic research, crypto and mainstream media. 

Our efforts have made the Optimism DAO ecosystem healthier, transparent and widely appreciated.

bio.text: Founder, DeepDAO.

links.name: Optimism Collective‚Äôs PRO dashboard on DeepDAO
links.description:
This is the most comprehensive source of truth on Optimism at the moment. It covers the OP Collective from all angles - treasury, token, votes, delegates, delegate coalitions, and place in the ecosystem. Each tab (you can click between them) includes multiple graphs and metrics, providing a nuanced look into the Collective‚Äôs inner workings. Below we have given short description to the sections of this dashboard, to fully illustrate its capabilities.

Note that the entire dashboard is free for everyone. 

Treasury
The treasury analysis provides a deeper look into what is going inside the Collective‚Äôs treasury. Starting with treasury change over time, it also lists the treasury currencies, and assets. Scrolling down, you can find a treasury composition percentage graph, a month by month total treasury value, and a list of all contracts related to the OP Collective. The contracts are labeled with the appropriate tags (liquid funds, protocol funds, governor, etc.)  

Token
Token analysis correlates the performance of the governance token ($OP) to governance metrics. The graphs of token price vs successful proposals, and average votes per proposal, help gauge governance sentiment and device plans to ensure a resilient voter set despite market conditions. This tab also includes a list of all DAOs holding the OP token in their treasury. 

Voter Trends
This tab provides deep insights on voter activity by tracking participation in various timeframes, and types of activity (proposals, avg. votes per proposals, and move). One can see how the total number of votes, voters, and average votes per proposal have changed over the past 3 years. The tab also provides analysis in shorter time frames over the past year, helping the Collective easily measure the impact of community and governance initiatives. 

Delegates
This is one of the most important sections of OP Collective‚Äôs PRO dashboard. Starting with a table on governance commitment - the tab displays delegates based on their number of delegators, voting power, and recent activity. Then it provides a comprehensive list of the most influential addresses in OP Collective, including delegates, badgeholders, and other stakeholders. What is proprietary and unique to DeepDAO is the historical governance profile for each of these addresses. Clicking on any of these profiles takes one to their profile page on DeepDAO, which displays their aggregate governance activity across the entire DAO ecosystem.  

Delegate Coalitions
Together with the delegates dashboard, the Coalitions dashboard provides a look at the people (addresses) that frequently vote together, and their combined power. This is a useful tool for understanding, and acting on the state of power concentration among the collective delegates - beyond any one individual. If one truly wants to know who are the influential delegates, the Coalitions dashboard is the place to look at. 

Ecosystem
The Ecosystem tab (scroll right to find it) provides insights on the place of the collective‚Äôs voters and delegates in the entire DAO ecosystem. It maps voters' interests in DAO sectors (as categorized by DeepDAO), and voters' engagement with other DAOs - the collective‚Äôs competitor, and partner DAOs. These insights provide a larger view on where the collective is, and has the power to feed into the collective's marketing initiatives.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

statement.answer:
DeepDAO provides the most comprehensive analysis of different components of Optimism governance:

- Treasury, including trends over time, tokens, assets and composition (OP vs stables, majors, and others).

-  Token, including governance performance influence on the OP token price.

- Voter Trends: multiple metrics of quality and intensity of governance participation in the Collective. Successful proposals, avg. votes per proposal, and others, in multiple timeframes. We also categorize voters based on their governance score to understand participant quality.

- Delegation, including intensity, and quantity of involvement across voting power, delegators, total votes, and voting periods.

- Delegate Coalitions, tracking governance activity of power groups of up to 6 addresses. Together with Delegation, this provides deep analysis of decentralization within Optimism governance.

- Voters Ecosystem, measuring the Collective voters involvement in other DAOs, including competing DAOs.
statement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?

statement.answer:
New Participants: DeepDAO helps new entrants to the DAO ecosystem discover the OP Collective, ensuring they do not face information asymmetry compared to experienced participants.

Delegates use DeepDAO to stay updated on OP Collective activities. Our analytics dashboard offers extensive information on the DAO's well-being.

Builders: DeepDAO makes it easy for builders to identify and approach the right delegates for feedback. (using the Delegation, and Coalitions dashboards).

Tooling Providers: DeepDAO aggregates information across various tooling providers and includes a tools page listing all DAO tools available to the Optimism Collective.

OP Collective: Our data on coalitions, governance segmentation and voter trends provides multiple indicators of the DAO‚Äôs decentralization, governance resilience and security. The Collective benefits immensely from a free resource like DeepDAO.

Investors, journalists, researchers: 1000s of media articles and academic papers quote DeepDAO data.

name: Praise
description:
Praise is an open-source reputation and rewards system designed to recognize, track, and verify community contributions across decentralized ecosystems. By offering simple tools that integrate with both Discord and Farcaster, Praise empowers communities to mint on-chain attestations and cultivate identity and reputation.
Through peer recognition on platforms Discord and more recently Farcaster, Praise enables users to acknowledge contributions, whether large or small, and reward them with verifiable on-chain attestations. These attestations, built on Ethereum Attestation Service (EAS), are seamlessly minted and integrated into users‚Äô decentralized identities and reputation.

name: OP Governance Trackor
description:
I was ex governance co-lead at blockchain@USC (delegating on behalf of a16z) at the OP Collective. At the time, I realized there were no public accountability for delegates meanwhile lots of them receive huge amount of votes. And to help the collective better monitor delegates, especially the top 100 of them, I consult with people like Justine (OP head of gov), Ross (a16z), Michael Silberling (OP Data), and lots of delegates on the metrics to track for governance. 

Thus, I created 2 public dune dashboards for the OP Collective to track the governance "performance" of its delegates. One is for the top 100 delegates. The other is for the a16z Optimism Delegates (including university clubs, professional delegate groups, and a few crypto native delegates. They track votes participations, voting powers, voting rationales, and other relevant metrics (on both individual level and the aggregate level). It help the OP collective to identify active and inactive delegates (with lots of voting power) to reward accordingly and conduct liquid delegation when performance degrades. It also help the delegators  such as a16z's and others to know which smaller voting power delegates are active in governance: offering them a platform for delegators to know more about them.

- Voting Bloc power over time: tracks the top100 or individual voting power over time
- Voting Cost: total gas cost across votes and average gas cost per delegate
- Inactive Delegates: who are they and how many votes they have
- Underrated Delegates: who have little voting power but has been consistently voting and has high-non-conformity score
- Statistics on Delegate Profiling: delegates who are self delegates vs those who have more than 1 delegators

name: Badgeholder Onchain Analysis
description:
The "Badgeholder Onchain Analysis" project is part of our submission to the Optimism retro funding!
As a dedicated research team, we are committed to providing comprehensive and insightful analyses within the ecosystem. Our current focus is on understanding the engagement and activity levels of Badgeholders across both superchain and non-superchain networks.
Our project delves deep into various aspects of on-chain activities, comparing Badgeholders with non-Badgeholders across different metrics. We analyze transaction count percentiles, category engagement, and application usage, providing a detailed view of user behaviour and preferences within the ecosystem. Our findings highlight key differences in transaction volumes, application preferences, and engagement levels across different user segments, offering valuable insights into the community's dynamics.
A significant aspect of our research is the integration with Farcaster, where we examine the level of cross-platform engagement among Badgeholders. Additionally, we explore the advanced engagement of Badgeholders by analyzing their smart contract deployment activities.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

statement.answer:
Our analysis measures the participation and behavior of Badgeholders in the Superchain ecosystem, specifically focusing on their transaction activities across networks like OP Mainnet, Base, Zora, and Mode. It also examines their engagement in decentralized applications (DEXs), token transfers, and social platforms like Farcaster. 

A key insight is the relatively low activity level of Badgeholders compared to Non-Badgeholders, particularly in areas like DEX trading and smart contract deployment. Additionally, the analysis tracks how Badgeholders' preferences for Ethereum transactions and limited cross-chain activity impact their overall engagement with Optimism's governance processes. 

This helps identify where governance structures may need to be adjusted to include better and activate Badgeholders, ensuring their participation grows alongside the broader ecosystem.
statement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?

statement.answer:
The Optimism Collective has benefitted most from this analysis, gaining valuable insights into Badgeholder behavior that inform strategies to increase engagement. For example, understanding that Badgeholders are more active on Ethereum but less engaged with smart contract deployment helps the Collective target these users with specific governance initiatives. 

Furthermore, the findings around Farcaster connections show the importance of social engagement within this group, which can shape future governance outreach and participation efforts. The insights have also helped governance teams refine their strategies for promoting cross-chain activity and diversifying user engagement. This research will also guide the future selection of new Badgeholders for the Citizen House by identifying gaps and ensuring the House becomes more inclusive and representative of the entire user profile within the Collective, promoting a well-rounded governance structure.

name: Impact Calculator Experiment
description:
The Impact Calculator experiments with converting quantitative insights into numeric impact evaluations for Retro Funding 4 and beyond. Traditionally, voting in Retro Funding involved manually reviewing and comparing individual applications to allocate tokens, relying heavily on the experience of citizens.

We collaborated with OpenSource Observer and Jonas from Optimism Foundation to design a new method that uses quantitative data to evaluate projects, allowing voters to focus on what matters to them.

Our prototype, along with BuidlGuidl's, found practical ways to implement a voting UI and accelerate the development of a metric-based voting system for Retro Funding 4.

statement.answer:
The Impact Calculator significantly enhanced the decision-making process for Retro Funding 4 by measuring the tangible real-world impact of each project, rather than relying on popularity metrics. This approach aligned with Optimism‚Äôs mission to reward high-impact contributions to the ecosystem.

By converting raw data into quantifiable metrics, the tool enabled badgeholders to evaluate projects more objectively and efficiently, reducing assessment time while ensuring impactful projects receive recognition and funding.

Our infrastructure and tooling support Optimism Governance by providing a transparent, data-driven evaluation framework, automating impact assessments, and ensuring fair resource allocation without subjective criteria‚Äîadvancing the governance goal of fostering sustainable growth.
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
Small builders have benefited the most from our infrastructure and tooling. They no longer need to compete with large, well-known projects for visibility. By creating impactful contributions, even on a smaller scale, they can access Retro Funding, which rewards based on real-world impact rather than recognition. This levels the playing field for those with fewer resources, enabling them to receive the funding they deserve.

Badgeholders also benefit significantly from our tooling. We‚Äôve automated much of the data they previously had to review manually, streamlining their evaluation process. This allows them to assess projects more quickly and accurately, ensuring a fair and transparent voting process while maintaining the integrity of Optimism Governance.

organization.name: Ari Juels's research group at Cornell Tech
organization.description:
Ari Juels is the Weill Family Foundation and Joan and Sanford I. Weill Professor in the Jacobs Technion-Cornell Institute at Cornell Tech and a Computer Science faculty member at Cornell University. He is a Co-Director of the Initiative for CryptoCurrencies and Contracts (IC3). He is also Chief Scientist at Chainlink Labs. Finally, he is the author of crypto thriller THE ORACLE (Talos Press, 2024).

His research group at Cornell Tech includes five PhD students, and also includes contributions by collaborators in the blockchain industry and interns. His group is best known recently for having initiated the study of (and coined the term) MEV, for its innovations in oracle systems, including the first zkTLS system (DECO), and for its seminal work on trusted execution environments (TEEs) in blockchains, such as the Ekiden platform.

name: Voting-Bloc Entropy (VBE)
description:
We are a group of academic researchers who have devised Voting-Bloc Entropy (VBE, pronounced "vibe"), a new metric for decentralization in DAOs. We have worked collaboratively with the Optimism Foundation to provide a toolkit to measure VBE in both the Citizens House and Token House to study their levels of decentralization. We have also released a public dashboard measuring VBE across DAOs. (Optimism Collective, as it turns out, ranks #1, i.e., has the highest VBE.)

We can't build truly equitable and durable DAOs unless we understand the meaning of the 'D' in DAO‚Äîthe decentralization part‚Äîand can measure it. Existing metrics‚Äîthe Nakamoto coefficient, the Gini coefficient, etc.‚Äîhave a number of shortcomings. We have proposed a new metric, called voting-block entropy (VBE)‚Äîpronounced "vibe." It measures decentralization in a principled way that avoids the pitfalls of previous metrics and better reflects intuitive notions of decentralization, such as diversity of opinions, credible neutrality, etc.

VBE additionally offers practical guidance for DAO administrators and users. Using VBE as a theoretical foundation, we have proven a number of basic theorems about ways to increase VBE and thus improve decentralization. 

Our work on VBE has involved strong collaboration with the Optimism Foundation (OF). In consultation with the OF, we have developed tools for the OF (and other projects) for measuring VBE. We have shared the resulting code for the Optimism-specific VBE toolkit with the Optimism Foundation for their use in analysis of the Optimism DAOs. We have also created a public dashboard at https://tinyurl.com/y2ftwavu that includes up-to-date VBE measurements for a number of major DAOs in the ecosystem. (Optimism, as it turns out, is currently #1, i.e., exhibits the highest VBE.)

Our team consists of researchers associated with Ari Juels's group at Cornell Tech.

* oVBE Dashboard Code: This repository contains the code for the Observable Voting Bloc Entropy (oVBE) Dashboard, a tool for analyzing Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO) voting data.

Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

statement.answer:
We formulated a new **measure of decentralization** that applies to the Optimism Collective's two houses and offers scientifically grounded **guidance** for improvement. This metric is called _voting-bloc entropy_ (VBE, pronounced "vibe"). It is being used for measurements in three ways:

* In close consultation with Optimism, we developed Optimism-specific **software tools** for measuring VBE that are now being used by the Optimism Collective to understand voting behaviors and Optimism governance more broadly. 
* We have launched a **public dashboard** that presents VBE measurements across the DAO ecosystem and includes Optimism and other leading DAOs. See https://t.co/2BqeTJtkNI. (Optimism is #1 by a nose, i.e., currently shows the highest VBE.)
* VBE is proving an **important metric** for DAO decentralization study, as highlighted by its inclusion in, e.g., a recent Optimism Foundation Mission Request (#183).
statement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?

statement.answer:
Beneficiaries of the three forms of measurement above include:

1. The **Gov Team at Optimism** helped shape the software tools to benefit from their use in analyzing past and future voting rounds (e.g., RetroPGF rounds), conducting experiments, and improving governance practices.
2. The **broad DAO and DeFi community** can now assess DAO decentralization across the ecosystem at a glance on our VBE dashboard---and the **Optimism Collective** benefits from showcasing of its strong commitment to and comparatively high degree of decentralization.
3. **Teams performing research** for the Optimism Collective benefit from a rigorous metric for decentralization and supporting Optimism-specific software tools.

name: Superfluid
description:
Superfluid is the leading asset streaming protocol that brings reward distributions like airstreams, vesting and team compensation to DAOs and crypto-native businesses worldwide.

The protocol has been live on Optimism since March 2022 and on Base since July 2023. It has been empowering developers with a crypto-native financial primitive, money streaming, and a modular smart contracts framework to build applications that leverage a formula-based balance and gasless, liquid, ongoing value transfer.

Over 49,394 streams have been started on Optimism and 644,584 on Base for a combined total volume of over $280M.

Superfluid is designed to minimize its TVL in favor of making assets available to sender or recipient at all times, minimizing funds locked in smart contracts. As such its impact is better measures in total volume transferred, number of total or active streams, total number of users and daily active users. When measuring the protocol activity it's important to not only rely on the on-chain transaction to smart contracts, but also on the the inner mechanics of the protocol (i.e. by evaluating the actions triggered via callData or by using the protocol subgraph).

On the alignment with Optimism and Retro Funding
- Superfluid is builder-centric. A developer tool with clear focus on onboarding more developers to build more apps. As such, it‚Äôs additive to Optimism‚Äôs own goals.
- Superfluid is supporting long term, real world use cases, like Salaries, Subscriptions, Memberships, Rentals, Airdrops, Grants distribution as well as entirely novel applications in DeFi, SocialFi and beyond.

Superfluid Protocol has been used by the Optimism Foundation to stream the RPGF3 & RF4 grants, and will be used again in the upcoming rounds, providing the rails for a seamless funds distribution.

The protocol has been designed around builders and developers, with a set of tools available for building, debugging and data retrieval that empower new applications development. Here you can see an overview of projects built on Superfluid that have added value (and usage) to the Optimism and Base networks: https://www.superfluid.finance/post/how-superfluid-protocol-is-empowering-onchain-builders

If you have any questions or would like to learn more about Superfluid, please reach out to mdali.eth on Warpcast or Twitter/X.

statement.answer:
Prior to the introduction of Superfluid Protocol in the retro funding process grant recipients had to claim their funds via direct interaction with Optimism's smart contracts, mostly by using the block explorer interface to make a contract call.

With the introduction of Superfluid recipients can see the total amount of OP awarded to them and the detailed timeline of the grant payout. They can also manage their incoming stream by redirecting it (or splitting it) to team members, third parties or DeFi apps in real time. You can read more about stream redirection and splitting here: https://help.superfluid.finance/en/articles/8907702-how-to-split-your-incoming-rpgf-grant

Superfluid also enabled smooth funds distribution, management and control for the Optimism team.

The entire community could benefit from transparent and easy to understand funding process, timeline and status (i.e. https://dune.com/0xkhmer/retropgf-3).

name: Pairwise
description:
Pairwise was designed to make voting in Retro Funding simple and fun. Pairwise is an open-source, off-chain voting dapp (like Snapshot) that streamlines community signaling by letting users select between just two options and then aggregating their choices into a quantifiable result.
Pairwise is designed to be user-friendly and intuitive, allowing users to make many simple choices and then the algorithm behind the scenes pumps out a final ranking for them to adjust or approve. 

* RF3: Served as an alternative tool for creating lists and subcategories for 600+ projects.
* RF4: Ran its own independent experiment enabling different stakeholder groups to signal how to distribute RF promoting project discovery with pseudonymous voting.
* RF5: After our great work on RF4, we were invited to be an official voting option to gamify and simplify the badgeholder decision making process. Allowing Badgeholders to create their ballot using our app.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

statement.answer:
We developed Pairwise for RF3, and introduced category voting to make the impact measurement in the Retro Funding more organic and manageable.

In RF3, 185 users engaged, 27 badgeholders using their key.

In RF4, we expanded into a community experiment using pseudonymous voting with zk-tech. This allowed all stakeholders‚Äîbadgeholders, token holders, recipients, and delegates‚Äîto participate freely without pressure and promote project discovery. We also distributed 4,000 OP as rewards, a 100OP to 40 lucky winners. Here you can find the [final results](https://www.pairwise.vote/rf4-results), and our [blog conclusions](https://paragraph.xyz/@pairwise) for more details on our outcomes.

The feedback from RF4 was very positive, leading to an invite to build with Optimism for RF5. For this round, we developed a star rating system, enabling participants to assign stars to projects before comparing them. This system grouped projects into tiers, significantly reducing the number of comparisons.
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
The main target when developing the product were badgeholders, who can use Pairwise, to rank Retro Funding projects in a fun way that promotes project discovery.

However, the entire Optimism community that used the app discovered impactful projects, bringing more visibility to emerging initiatives.

Projects benefited from this increased exposure to potential users. Pairwise also sparks discussions by comparing its results to official ones, fostering deeper insights and driving more meaningful participation and progress to decentralization.

The foundation‚Äôs implementation of RetroFunding was clearly informed by our work and [feedback](https://gov.optimism.io/t/retropgf-round-3-feedback-thread/6177/150?u=griff). Enabling categorical voting, and ranking projects then adjusting percentages were done in Pairwise before they were considered to be implemented in RF5&RF6. Subtracting grant amounts and soliciting comments from badgeholders were also inspired by our work, but cut from scope.

name: Optimism Fractal Respect Game Events
description:
Optimism Fractal is a community dedicated to fostering collaboration, awarding public good creators, and optimizing governance on the Optimism Superchain. We host weekly Respect Game events, featuring a unique onchain social game designed to foster collaboration, award public goods creators, and optimize governance on the Superchain. Between October 2023 and September 2024, we hosted 42 events where participants share their contributions to Optimism, rank each other‚Äôs impact with onchain attestations, and earn non-transferable Respect tokens.

These Respect tokens create a transparent, peer-reviewed system for measuring governance contributions and impact. Optimism Fractal events are a hub for pioneering fractal democracy on Optimism, providing a scalable model for decentralized decision-making. Through this gamified approach, we're shaping the future of Optimism governance, connecting builders, and community leaders while fostering a culture of active governance participation.

This project is for the hosting, promoting, organizing, and producing of respect game events, as well as other key processes like community engagement and facilitation of our consensus processes. It does include not the development of tools used at the events or the Optimism Town Hall events which take place after Respect Game events, as there are separate applications for these projects.

This work has not been funded by the Collective outside of the RetroPGF Round 3 grant shown below, which supported the team who started Optimism Fractal as well as our work with several other related projects. You can see Optimystics.io/projects-and-funding details on our organization‚Äôs funding and applications for related projects.

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

statement.answer:
1. Respect Game: We've refined this core process, enabling peer evaluation of governance contributions to Optimism and creating a decentralized reputation system crucial for governance.

2. Decentralized Governance Structures: Our weekly council selection and proposal review processes, based on Respect earnings, demonstrate a practical model of decentralized decision-making.

3. Governance Builder Showcases: We provide a regular forum for developers to present governance-related tools and innovations, while collaborating with others.

4. Governance Education: Our events serve as an interactive platform for newcomers to engage with innovative Optimism governance processes.

5. Stakeholder Collaboration: We foster connections between delegates, council members, and builders, creating a more cohesive governance ecosystem and facilitating knowledge exchange.

These consistent events create a stable environment for ongoing governance experimentation and refinement on Optimism.
statement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?

statement.answer:
1. Enhanced Governance Participation: We've increased engagement in Optimism governance by providing a regular, accessible entry point, attracting over 50 leaders to actively participate in governance practices (and many more viewers).

2. Decentralized Reputation: The Respect token earned at our events has created a nuanced measure of governance contributions, improving decision-making processes and impact measurement.

3. Governance Development: By providing a stable platform for governance experimentation and connecting participants, we've enabled the development of several open-source governance tools and inspired other communities to build on Optimism with these tools.

4. Scalable Governance Model: Our fractal approach has demonstrated how large-scale governance decisions can be made efficiently in a decentralized manner in all other aspects of Optimism governance.

These improvements have strengthened Optimism's governance, making it more effective, inclusive, and resilient.

statement.answer:
The **Delegate Match Farcaster Frame** is designed to improve accessibility in Optimism governance by helping OP token holders find active delegates who align with their values and vision. The tool streamlines the process, allowing users to take an 11-question survey and match with active, values-aligned delegates, increasing the overall votable OP supply. [Landing page](https://delegatematch.xyz/)

Leveraging Farcaster‚Äôs 650K registered users and 60-100K daily active users, Delegate Match boosts exposure to the OP delegation process. Our Farcaster Frame provides a seamless experience, enabling users to make an informed decision and delegate their tokens in just five minutes. By integrating the Ethereum Attestation Service, Delegate Match supports delegate reputation-building. It provides OP holders and delegates a low-cost, high-impact, innovative delegation tool. [Onchain Metrics](https://hackmd.io/@Suede/rJaRn0UJJe)
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
The main beneficiaries of **Delegate Match** are OP token holders who aren‚Äôt too engaged in governance and OP delegates with active delegations. Holders can easily find and delegate or redelegate to active delegates who align with their values. OP delegates, particularly underrepresented ones, benefit from increased visibility to grow their delegations based on values alignment rather than popularity. By encouraging broader participation, Delegate Match helps decentralize governance and promotes greater equity among delegates, enabling them to play a more meaningful role in Optimism's decision-making.

We have a solid foundation and are passionately engaged in exploring innovative solutions in this uncharted territory. Our impact included critical inquiries into user experience, impact tracking, and outreach strategies so that delegation is informed, accessible, accountable, and efficient for all stakeholders. Delve into our [Vision and Insights](https://hackmd.io/@Suede/HJaVrJw1ye)

statement.answer:
Gitcoin developed the voting interfaces for Retrofunding 4 & Retrofunding 5, which were used by badgeholders to allocate funds during those rounds. We worked closely with Agora, who powered the API, and Optimism, who outlined the requirements and provided designs.

For RF4, we worked closely with Open Source Observer and Optimism to implement new metrics-based discovery, selection, and weighting. Our solution allowed users to filter and evaluate projects based on various impact metrics. 

For both RF 4 & RF5, we created a user-friendly interface for governance participants to allocate their votes. 

These tools are primarily used within Optimism Governance to support the Retroactive Public Goods Funding process, which is a crucial part of Optimism's governance model. They aim to make the process of discovering, evaluating, and voting for projects more efficient, transparent, and user-friendly for governance participants.

Though RF5 is still ongoing at the time of this application, participation is high. Badgeholders are expected to allocate between 2-8m OP tokens to up to 89 projects.

The team has also integrated these features into EasyRetroPGF.xyz, which makes them available to a wider range of users involved in Optimism's governance processes. The SUNNYS Awards have also been built on this same technology!
