organization.name: OpenRank
organization.description: OpenRank is a decentralized ranking and reputation protocol. It enables a verifiable reputation compute layer for the open web that unlocks a broad range of useful applications, including those that resist cryptographic or game-theoretic mechanisms of trust. Using graph compute algorithms like EigenTrust, it offers resilience from sybil contexts, provides scalable and context-specific compute, and enables permissionless access to compute and reputation data for any developer.

name: Retro 4 Metrics: Trusted User Models and OpenRank Trusted User Model
description:
[WHAT WE DID]

Retro 4 pioneered the experiment of impact metrics, amongst which is the importance of defining valuable users interacted with applications on the superchain. Trusted User Model was introduced to measure the count of users qualified for the Trusted User definition. 

Several data sources were used to compose the Trusted User definition. The Farcaster user reputation scores computed by OpenRank on an curated engagement graph was used as one of the three major data sources, next to FIDs and Gitcoin Passport. 

The reputation scores are taken from OpenRank Farcaster Global Profile Ranking: Farcaster users are basically categorized into the two strategies: [**following**](https://docs.openrank.com/integrations/farcaster/global-profile-ranking#strategy-following) and [**engagement](https://docs.openrank.com/integrations/farcaster/global-profile-ranking#strategy-engagement), and ranked recursively by incoming and outgoing trusted engagement signals such as recast, comment, likes on their social graph.** This score is made available, open-sourced and verifiable by OpenRank reputation protocol.

[OUR IMPACT]

Users which rank high on OpenRank scores are acknowledged lost of developers as highly likely to be reputable real users instead of spam, Sybils and scammers. 

https://gov.optimism.io/t/retro-funding-4-impact-metrics-a-collective-experiment/8226
Additionally, Retro 4 also used a metric called OpenRank Trusted User Model, which indicates an even tougher-defined trust. Therefore it is a good metric to measure the contribution of an app on Optimism. 

[WHAT IS OpenRank]

OpenRank is a decentralized ranking and reputation protocol. It enables a verifiable reputation compute layer for the open web that unlocks a broad range of useful applications, including those that resist cryptographic or game-theoretic mechanisms of trust. Using graph compute algorithms like EigenTrust, it offers resilience from sybil contexts, provides scalable and context-specific compute, and enables permissionless access to compute and reputation data for any user.

statement.answer:
Badgeholder votes are private. This allows voters to express their true preferences without fear of retaliation, coercion, or pressure from others. It makes it difficult to execute vote buying, and encourages honest participation. It doesn't protect against the vote counter cheating.

Even though the allocation algorithm is public (and we can check that it accurately codifies forum promises), we can‚Äôt run a check without the input data. In the worst case, we can‚Äôt guarantee that the provided allocation algorithm was even used or that all votes were counted.

We made this process transparent with zero-knowledge (ZK) proof that legitimate votes were counted and that the allocation algorithm was run as intended, keeping the votes themselves private. Using EZKL, we were able to compile the Python allocation code into a circuit, and provide a proof anyone can verify at https://retrofunding.ezkl.xyz (see https://blog.ezkl.xyz/post/zkrpgf/ for more details).
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
The Retroactive Public Goods Funding process ideally improves with each round via governance feedback. We cryptographically audited Round 3 in a replicable way, providing a cryptographic proof any stakeholder can verify in a browser. This paves the way for an end-to-end automated process with private voting, checks and balances on the allocation algorithm, and smart contract enabled allocation delivery

For stakeholders, this cryptographic audit means many things:
- For badgeholders, your vote was fairly counted
- For recipients, your allocation was fairly calculated
- For everyone else, the results actually correspond with Optimism governance ‚Äî governance at work!

Blockchains have both social consensus (which fork is the main one, which client should be run, etc.) and computational consensus. By verifying the RetroPGF results, everyone helps solidify the social consensus around the legitimacy of the vote. You are an election observer, contributing to a successful audit.

name: Optimism Delegate Frame on Farcaster
description:
The ‚ÄúOptimism Delegate Frame‚Äù on Farcaster is a useful tool that makes OP delegation easy and accessible. With this frame, users can quickly check who their OP delegate is and re-delegate their voting power if they choose.

It starts with the ‚ÄúCheck My Delegate‚Äù button, showing key info like wallet address, OP balance, and the current delegate. A user can then pick a new delegate by entering their wallet address, ENS, or Farcaster handle and confirming through their wallet.

Once complete, the user gets a confirmation with transaction details and can share it with others on Farcaster. The tool integrates Optimism‚Äôs delegation function, making it straightforward for anyone to participate in governance.

The frame is made by Tempe Techie and Tekr, both delegates and builders in the Optimism ecosystem. We are also very active on Farcaster, which is why we decided to build a tool that is useful to both us and others on Farcaster.

statement.answer:
Many people don‚Äôt often think about whom they delegate their tokens to, or whether they have delegated them at all. Our frame reminds users of the delegation option, allowing them to review and choose a different delegate. 

Everything happens within the Farcaster app, with no need to go outside of it, making the process more convenient. The frame makes delegation easy and encourages people to think about governance.

The tool is in the form of a frame, which is a Farcaster invention. It‚Äôs essentially a link preview on steroids. Frames can include buttons and text fields that allow users to interact directly with them. A frame is basically a mini-app within Farcaster.
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
Citizens and delegates active on Farcaster have benefited the most from the Optimism Delegate Frame. 

Delegates can share pre-filled frames with their information, making it easy for users to delegate to them with just a few clicks. This system allows delegates to promote themselves while reminding citizens to check their current delegate and switch if they choose. 

Since these frames are shared publicly on Farcaster, they help raise awareness about Optimism governance and encourage more users to engage with the delegation process.

name: DAOstar
description:
DAOstar is the non-profit standards body for DAOs. We build important public goods that make DAOs more transparent and interoperable. Our contributions to OP Collective include: 
- maintenance and upgrades to EIP-4824 infrastructure. EIP-4824 creates a global source of truth that is owned and managed by a DAO. Through our efforts, we helped publish and maintain a EIP-4824 compliant daoURI for OP Collective. 
- To make the compliance easier, we also built two additional EIP-4824 adoption pathways, through ENS txt records and EAS attestations. 
- development of DAO Attestation Registry, a website for listing DAO-related schemas deployed on EAS
- several other initiatives to address the common pain points of OP Collective and other DAOs, including regulatory interoperability and access to underrepresented markets like Asia.

statement.answer:
- Data interoperability and transparency within the Collective: The Optimism Collective is one of the largest DAOs, with new artifacts being released continuously. Through EIP-4824, we have created an on-chain (and off-chain) source of truth on the Optimism Collective. New artifacts can be continuously added to the Collective's daoURI, making it comprehensive over time. 

- Better visibility for DAO-related EAS schemas on Optimism: Currently, there is no place where DAO-related EAS schemas can be listed and indexed, along with a description and additional context. We built a proof-of-concept DAO Schema Registry.

- Visibility into grants. Working with OSO and Gitcoin, we have developed an initial data lake for grants across Web3, including Optimism's grants, combating grant farming and double dipping across ecosystems.
statement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?

statement.answer:
- Governance tooling providers: More transparency and interoperability of data direclty benefit Snapshot, Snapshot X, and a variety of other governance tools, who utilize EIP-4824 to publish and handle DAO metadata.

- New participants of the OP Collective: the daoURI is a useful piece of infrastructure for anyone who'd like to find info at a single location.

- Delegates: More data transparency and standardization makes it easier for even high-context individuals to assess changes across the scope of a wide, decentralized organization.

- Grantees: Our work on grants management improves the odds of genuine projects' access to capital. It also helps the Optimism Collective reward contributions more efficiently.

name: Mission Tracking Dashboard Season5
description:
As an active contributor to the Optimism DAO, I have proactively led multiple grants analyses and taken initiative to build tools that bring real value to both delegates and grant applicants. The Mission Tracking Dashboard for Season 5 was designed with a clear purpose‚Äîto bring structure and visibility to a chaotic process and make mission tracking simpler, more transparent, and efficient for everyone involved.

Key features and values of the dashboard include:

Centralized Access: All essential resources‚Äîapplication templates, guides, social channels, and workshop recordings‚Äîwere brought together in one platform, making it easy to navigate.

Live, Intent-Wise Tracking: The dashboard offered real-time updates on mission requests by intent, providing crucial details such as requested budgets, proposer information, number of applicants, and current status. This allowed applicants to easily decide which mission requests to apply for.

Voting Insights: During the voting phase, the dashboard proved invaluable by providing clear visibility into all passed mission requests, ensuring transparency and enabling informed decision-making for both delegates and voters.

Enhanced Engagement: By providing real-time updates and key resources in one place, the dashboard increased engagement from both delegates and grant applicants, allowing them to follow the process seamlessly.

Scalability: As the number of mission requests and proposals increased, the dashboard helped manage the growing complexity, offering a structured and organized solution that controlled everything.

By proactively creating this tool, I brought clarity, structure, and engagement to what can often be a complex and chaotic process. The Mission Tracking Dashboard became essential to ensuring smooth operations, benefiting both delegates and grant applicants during Season 5.

organization.name: Fracton Research
organization.description: Fracton Research is an R&D institution for a positive sum world through exploring inclusive coordination design. Our focus is to solve coordination problems and public goods problems such as the free-rider problem and tragedy of the commons, and to create positive externalities through coordination mechanisms based on blockchain: regenerative funding mechanisms, collective decision making, and other protocol design. Also, we will collaborate with profit/non-profit organizations, academic institutions, and government, so we will achieve them by getting experience and knowledge from practical fieldworks.

name: Fracton Research - Retrospective Quantitative Review of Grants
description:
This research aims to improve governance by achieving more effective public goods funding through the comparison of various grant models. Grant programs play a crucial role in the crypto ecosystem, but comparative studies are rare. In this study, we compare different types of programs such as Uniswap, dYdX, Optimism, and Gitcoin, categorizing them into "top-down," "bottom-up," and "QF (algorithmic)" types. Our findings suggest that bottom-up and QF types tend to distribute funds more evenly, with smaller grant amounts and less variability, while top-down types exhibit greater variability and tend to provide larger grants to fewer recipients.

The goal of this research is to achieve a more effective and fair grants program. We aim to uncover the differences among various grant programs and provide insights that could improve future program management. By conducting a cross-comparative quantitative analysis, focusing especially on decision-making bodies, we investigated how grant amounts and the number of grants are influenced by different types of decision-making mechanisms. Looking ahead, we plan to develop tools for impact evaluation, impact measurement, or outcome measurement based on these results. This will enable evidence-based public goods funding by using grants data, ensuring that future grants are more effective and aligned with measurable outcomes.

This research and development includes Optimism Collective as a subject of investigation, focusing on identifying the unique characteristics of the Optimism Collective, analyzing the current state of its fund distribution, and comparing it with other grant programs. This approach will contribute to designing more effective, evidence-based funding strategies and to realizing the vision of Retro Funding.

links.name: A Retrospective Quantitative Review of Crypto Grants Programs
links.description:
In this survey, I quantitatively compared grant amounts among the programs implemented by Uniswap, dYdX, Optimism, and Gitcoin to find the differences among them. This survey revealed trends based on the characteristics of the grants programs managers (decision-makers). In Uniswap and dYdX, the grants programs are operated by a few arbitrarily selected individuals (top-down type), Optimism is managed by individuals elected or selected based on objective criteria (bottom-up type), and Gitcoin uses a direct democratic method called Quadratic Funding (QF type) where decisions are made by a large number of people. The hypothesis that could be drawn from categorizing these operations is that there is a correlation with the amount of grants. The bottom-up and QF types tend to distribute funds more evenly with smaller variability and smaller grant amounts. Conversely, the top-down type shows greater variability in the amounts received by each grantee, and fewer recipients in general. This means that while bottom-up and QF types distribute grants more evenly, providing a sort of economic infrastructure, the top-down type shows a kind of bias with a greater variability in grant amounts, with fewer recipients receiving larger. This suggests that bottom-up and QF types tend to fund projects with high public utility, whereas top-down types are more likely to fund projects that benefit their own protocols, reflecting a fundamental difference in the underlying motivations of each grants program.

However, while the bias introduced by top-down grants may seem negative from a fairness perspective, I consider this bias important. This aligns with traditional economic theory, where governments intervene to provide goods that are difficult to manage in the market. Top-down granters can play a role similar to government intervention, providing funds for projects that fall outside the scope of QF, potentially introducing serendipity in the public goods market. Therefore, the bias in top-down grants programs may bring positive outcomes when viewed from the ecosystem as a whole. There may be a need for environments that produce diverse grants programs aiming to provide public goods based on certain or biased values. At the same time, funding "outliers" needs feedback and accountability from the grantee to the grantor, or this means the importance of funding systems based on project outcomes, though general grants programs need too. In the future, measuring the outcomes of grantees can help grantors focus on the types of projects that are most beneficial. Organizations like Venture Grantor, as well as VCs and foundations focused on the provision and maintenance of public goods, will also value this role.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

statement.answer: Our analysis identifies the characteristics of the fund distribution methods used in the Optimism Collective‚Äôs grant programs by comparing them with other grant programs. We analyze distribution patterns, such as the size of grants, the number of recipients, decision-making processes, and how evenly resources are allocated, highlighting how Optimism‚Äôs fund distribution differs from other governance models. We have found that Optimism provides relatively larger grants, supports a greater number of recipients, and shows less variation in the amount granted per recipient. We also examine how effective Optimism‚Äôs governance structure is in promoting fair and impactful public goods funding. Additionally, we expect this analysis to lead to the proposal of new types of grants and the measurement and evaluation of impact based on data, contributing to more effective funding practices.
statement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?

statement.answer: The main beneficiaries of our analytical work are decision-makers involved in Optimism Collective‚Äôs grant distribution, as well as those looking to improve grant allocation models and governance mechanisms. By providing insights into fund distribution patterns and the effectiveness of different governance mechanisms, we support these stakeholders in making evidence-based decisions. This will enable the Optimism Collective to contribute to the Optimism ecosystem, the Ethereum ecosystem, and real-world public goods, making true public goods funding a reality through evidence-based decision-making. Our research helps contributors make informed decisions.

organization.name: Code of Conduct S5
organization.description: In S5, the Code of Conduct Council was pioneered for the first time to uphold governance standards within Optimism by enforcing the Code of Conduct, which went into effect in December 2021. Initially, the Foundation handled violation reports, and Token House delegates voted on enforcement, but this model became unsustainable as the ecosystem grew. To address concerns about impartiality and delegate discomfort in voting on violations, the Council was formed, undergoing two rescopings to refine its role.

name: Code of Conduct Council S5
description:
In S5, the Code of Conduct Council was pioneered for the first time to uphold governance standards within Optimism by enforcing the Code of Conduct, which went into effect in December 2021. Initially, the Foundation handled violation reports, and Token House delegates voted on enforcement, but this model became unsustainable as the ecosystem grew. To address concerns about impartiality and delegate discomfort in voting on violations, the Council was formed, undergoing two rescopings to refine its role.

Note: In the S5 scope for the role, it was intended that the majority of the funding be from RetroPGF. In S6, the budget was increased per member, and therefore that different team is not applying. From S5 budget: ‚ÄúEach Council member will receive a stipend of 3,000 OP at the end of the Season. As the activity level of the Code of Conduct Councils is unknown in advance (as it depends on the number of reports and disputes per Season), the majority of rewards for Code of Conduct Councils should be granted retroactively via RetroPGF.‚Äù

subcategory: Councils, Commissions and Advisory Boards; NERD programs focused exclusively on core governance responsibilities (GovNERDs)::This includes Security Council, Grants Council, Developer Advisory Board, Code of Conduct Council, Anticapture Commission, Collective Feedback Commissions and GovNERDs.

statement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024
statement.question: In what season did your work take place

statement.answer:
The Code of Conduct Council has significantly contributed to improving the enforcement of governance standards within Optimism. By taking over the processing of Code of Conduct violation reports, the Council has streamlined enforcement, removing the burden from Token House delegates and allowing them to focus on higher-level governance matters. During Season 5, no Code of Conduct issues were escalated to the Token House, despite multiple submissions occurring during this period. 
In Season 5, the Council implemented clear processes for handling disputes, including a transparent reporting system that publishes enforcement decisions. Also, confirming and denying grant clawback requests from the grants council smooth lined the process in how teams that hadn‚Äôt met their milestones would be treated. Further, initiatives like GravityDAO‚Äôs conflict resolution training demonstrated the Council‚Äôs commitment to preventative measures, reducing the likelihood of violations in the first place.
statement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?

statement.answer:
The Council helped foster a more accessible and fair enforcement process that clearly laid out the framework and operations around possible community violations. As this was the first cohort involved in the Code of Conduct, all members had to also reflect not only on the duties initially assigned by the original proposal, but also the potential for improvement and limitations of the system established and its Internal Operating Procedures.
The impact and want for something like this was proven apparent by the Council‚Äôs reapproval, this time with a new budget of up to 6000 OP per member (vs 3000 OP in S5). This shift has improved governance efficiency, ensuring timely and impartial enforcement of community standards. The introduction of preventative measures, such as conflict resolution training, further supports long-term community well-being. Through these, the Council has played a crucial role in maintaining Optimism‚Äôs integrity and promoting sustainable governance practices.

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

statement.answer:
EAS is foundational in Retro Funding and governance processes by providing structured, verifiable attestations that enhance accountability, trust, and accelerate decision-making.

In Retro Funding, EAS is used to:
- Provide unique IDs for projects and organizations
- Capture and update project/org metadata
- Log project submissions/applications to RF rounds
- Record approvals/rejections of applications
- Detail reward amounts

EAS also supports governance roles and contributions by representing citizenship status separately from voting rights, issuing voting badges for Retro Rounds, attesting to contributors in retro rounds, and recognizing those who held governance roles like Grants Council members.

View all schemas used by OP: https://docs.optimism.io/chain/identity/schemas

*Note:* Archived schemas have been utilized for RetroPGF3, Season 4, and Optimist Profiles.
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
EAS impacts all participants involved in the Retro Funding experience.

**Governance Teams Overseeing Retro Funding**
OP grants/governance teams rely on EAS for transparent and verifiable decision-making throughout the Retro Funding process. EAS enables them to operate more efficiently, experiment, build trust, and scale governance.

**Retro Funding Participants**
RF project creators, reviewers, and other participants use EAS when creating profiles, submitting applications, approving or rejecting projects, and updating metadata. EAS ensures these interactions are structured and verifiable for each step of the RF experience.

**Governance Tooling & Analytic Providers**
These teams access EAS attestations to retrieve data, generate reports, and gain insights. These attestations make it easier to analyze RF activities and contribute to better decision-making.

name: Measuring the Concentration of Power in Optimism
description:
Our project aimed to analyze the distribution and concentration of power within the Optimism Collective's governance structure, using a new metric called the Concentration of Power Index (CPI). Building on the traditional Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI), the CPI provided a nuanced perspective by evaluating the voting power of delegates and the roles of various governance bodies, including the Token House and Citizen House. Additionally, we examined the Nakamoto Coefficient to assess the minimum number of members needed to control a majority of voting power, allowing us to compare our findings for the Optimism Collective with those of other prominent DAOs like Compound, Aave, and Uniswap. This research was intended to inform future governance decisions, ensuring the Collective remained fair, transparent, and truly decentralized as it grew and evolved.

Our team consisted of three members who contributed to this project. Chain-l used his experience in the blockchain industry and DAOs to guide the development of the Concentration of Power Index and managed the overall research project. ARDev focused on data analysis, using his skills in ETL processes and Dune Analytics to gather and visualize the data collected, which informed our comparisons with other DAOs. Dhruvi contributed to data visualization to create clear and compelling dashboards that presented our findings in an accessible way, helping to illustrate the power dynamics within the Optimism Collective. Together, our combined efforts ensured a thorough and insightful analysis to be presented to the DAO and community members.

statement.answer:
Our work measures the concentration of power within Optimism Collective using the Concentration of Power Index (CPI), which assesses power dynamics across delegates and governance bodies like Houses, Councils, and Committees (HCC). 

For example, we analyzed the voting power of delegates in the Token House and the influence of the Citizens‚Äô House, Grants Council, Security Counci & Committeesl. Using this data, the CPI helps evaluate decentralization trends and power shifts over time, such as the reduction in CPI from 329.25 to 80.90 across multiple governance seasons. 

This analysis also highlights the interplay between individual voting power and collective influence, offering a more comprehensive view of decision-making within the governance structure. Our metrics provide a clear understanding of how power shifts with different members being appointed/elected in various HCCs.
statement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?

statement.answer:
The Optimism Collective community, including delegates & governance bodies  has benefited most from this analysis. It was also a requirement raised through a Foundation Mission Request which emphasised the importance of developing such a metric.

For instance, delegates can use CPI insights to understand the balance of power and make more informed decisions. Governance bodies like the Citizens‚Äô House and Token House also benefit by identifying areas where power is concentrated, allowing them to make policy adjustments that promote decentralization and ensure fairer representation across the ecosystem. 

Additionally, community‚Äôs leaders can leverage this data to track the effectiveness of decentralization efforts and proactively address emerging governance challenges. The broader community gains from this transparency, enabling more inclusive participation and fostering trust in the governance system.

links.name: Token Engineering the Superchain - Testing Hybrid Funding Experiments for the OP Ecosystem
links.description: The Token Engineering Commons (TEC) launched an innovative experiment in the second half of 2024, aiming to promote token engineering within the Optimism and Superchain ecosystems. This initiative combined Quadratic Funding (QF) with Retroactive Funding, introducing a novel capital allocation mechanism called Tunable Quadratic Funding (TQF). The experiment consisted of two rounds: a Gitcoin Grants 21 QF round in August, followed by a retroactive funding round in November using Gitcoin's EasyRetro on Allo Protocol. TEC will invest $50,000 across these rounds, with Gitcoin contributing an additional $50,000 match for the QF round. The project emphasizes Superchain impact, incorporating voting boosts for Superchain stakeholders and focusing on projects that catalyze token engineering adoption in the Superchain. Throughout the experiment, TEC organized educational events to explain token engineering and showcase grantees' work to key Superchain stakeholders, with the aim to build more trustworthy blockchain systems.

links.name: Results of Token Engineering the Superchain - TQF Report
links.description:
The Token Engineering the Superchain Grants Round: Summer/Fall 2024 delivered significant impact to the Optimism ecosystem through its innovative use of Tunable Quadratic Funding (TQF). By strategically boosting the voting weights of OP badgeholders and delegates, the round ensured that funding decisions were closely aligned with the expertise and priorities of key Optimism stakeholders. This approach resulted in the allocation of $60,000 across 18 carefully selected projects, each demonstrating strong potential to advance both token engineering principles and the Optimism Superchain ecosystem.

The TQF mechanism's focus on OP signals amplified the influence of community leaders, with OP Delegate Tokens Delegated receiving a 7x boost and OP Badgeholders an 8x boost. This targeted approach ensured that projects receiving funding were not only technically sound but also strongly aligned with Optimism's long-term vision and goals. As a result, the round saw a notable increase in projects directly addressing Superchain-specific challenges and opportunities, fostering innovation tailored to Optimism's unique ecosystem.

Moreover, the round's dual-phase structure, combining upfront quadratic funding with a planned retroactive funding phase, creates a powerful incentive for funded projects to deliver tangible results. This approach is poised to drive sustained, measurable impact within the Optimism ecosystem, encouraging projects to focus on real-world implementation and adoption of token engineering principles within the Superchain context. By leveraging the expertise of Optimism's most engaged community members through the TQF mechanism, this grants round has set a new standard for targeted, community-driven funding in the Web3 space, promising long-term benefits for both the token engineering field and the Optimism ecosystem at large.

links.name: Token Engineering the Superchain Grants Round Retro Report
links.description:
The Token Engineering the Superchain Grants Round for Summer/Fall 2024 demonstrated significant impact in advancing both token engineering and the Optimism ecosystem. With total distributions of $60k across 18 projects and total donations of $5,792.59 from 349 unique donors across 914 contributions, the round supported 18 carefully selected projects, each receiving an average grant of $3,333. This more focused approach, compared to previous rounds, led to stronger alignment with the dual objectives of advancing token engineering and driving Superchain impact. The round successfully implemented an innovative Tunable Quadratic Funding (TQF) mechanism, incorporating expertise signals to ensure aligned funding decisions.

Despite a decrease in overall participation compared to the previous round, the average contribution remained stable at $16.6, indicating sustained engagement from committed supporters. Notably, 11 out of 18 projects were returning grantees, suggesting continued progress and alignment with the ecosystem's goals. The round also set the foundation for a follow-up Retroactive Funding phase, emphasizing long-term impact and milestone achievement.

While facing challenges in areas such as application evaluation and project alignment guidance, the round provided valuable insights for future improvements. These include enhancing communication with potential grantees, refining the evaluation process, and improving support for project marketing. Overall, this grants round successfully funded high-potential projects while laying the groundwork for ongoing advancement in token engineering within the Optimism ecosystem, demonstrating the effectiveness of this focused, two-phase funding approach.

links.name: Token Engineering QF Grants Round: Spring 2024 GG20 Round Retro
links.description:
The Token Engineering QF Grants Round: Spring 2024 demonstrated significant impact and growth in advancing the field of token engineering. With a total distribution of $50k worth of $TEC across 32 projects, and crowdfunding of $9,365 raised from 554 unique donors, the round saw an impressive 83.3% increase in crowdfunding compared to the previous iteration. This growth extended to the number of participating projects, which rose by 60% to 32, including 23 new initiatives that more than doubled the influx of fresh ideas. The average contribution also increased substantially by 75.49% to $16.90, indicating heightened donor engagement and generosity.

The round successfully met its key objectives of supporting public good projects, encouraging innovation, and building a stronger community within the token engineering ecosystem. By funding a diverse range of projects across categories such as tooling, research, social infrastructure, and education, the round ensured a holistic advancement of the field. The implementation of the Tunable Quadratic Funding (TQF) Matching Boost and the involvement of nine seasoned advisors in the evaluation process enhanced the quality of funded projects and aligned support with genuine expertise.

Being selected as one of Gitcoin's sponsored community rounds significantly amplified the round's reach, attracting a wider array of projects and new perspectives. This expanded visibility, coupled with the round's focus on long-term impact assessment, has laid a strong foundation for the continued growth and maturation of the token engineering field. Grantees expressed appreciation for the trust and platform provided, while the lessons learned from this round will inform improvements for future iterations. Overall, the Token Engineering QF Grants Round: Spring 2024 marks a significant milestone in fostering innovation, supporting diverse projects, and engaging a growing community of contributors in the advancement of token engineering principles and practices.

links.name: Results of Token Engineering Grants Round 2
links.description:
The Token Engineering (TE) Grants Program concluded its second Quadratic Funding (QF) round as part of the Gitcoin Beta Round, which ran from August 15 to 29. This round was featured on Gitcoin and funded by TEC's Common Pool. The round had been configured with a $25,000 matching pool, a 20% matching cap, and a 2x coefficient multiplier for the TE Matching Boost.

The round saw significant engagement, with 14 projects participating and attracting 1,837 unique donors. A total of 2,608 contributions were made, raising $5,786.48 from donors, with an average contribution of $3.15. The top-performing project was the Bonding Curve Research Group (BCRG), which received 9,710.0293 $TEC. Other notable projects included DataBites (7,073.6435 $TEC), Dynamic Optimization Algorithm for Self-regulating Tokenomics (6,982.7264 $TEC), Commons Stack (6,044.8391 $TEC), and Index Wallets (5,533.4081 $TEC). In total, the round distributed 48,550.1464 $TEC across all participating projects.

links.name: TEC OP Migration
links.description:
The Token Engineering Commons (TEC) successfully completed its migration from Gnosis to Optimism (OP) Mainnet, aligning itself with Optimism's mission of scaling Ethereum and funding public goods. This move positioned TEC among like-minded entities dedicated to solving similar challenges in the blockchain ecosystem.

As part of the migration, TEC tokens for regular EOA holders were transferred to the same addresses on OP Mainnet. The TEC's Augmented Bonding Curve (ABC) switched from using xDai to Rocket Pool ETH (rETH) as collateral, linking the TEC token's value to this staked ETH derivative. New contract addresses were established for the TEC token (0x8fc7c1109c08904160d6ae36482b79814d45eb78), Common Pool (0xb941365430a16659658bb23b88efaede1d839354), and Reserve Pool (0xae34eb7c3163aad32142fbbcf15ec234c9ef173f).

The migration process also addressed special cases, including the consolidation of Lasertag's inactive assets into the Common Pool and the conversion of the Reward Board's wxDAI to rETH. These changes marked a significant step for the TEC community, setting the stage for continued growth and collaboration within the Optimism ecosystem.

links.name: TEC Dashboard
links.description: The dashboard showcases a comprehensive view of the TEC ecosystem. It displays crucial market information, including the market price of $TEC-$OP, along with sell and buy prices. The dashboard features prices for all SAMM TEC pairs and a TEC Price Chart for visual representation. It also tracks community engagement metrics such as the number of unique holders, their growth over time, and holder distribution. The TEC Coordination team's activities are transparent, with the dashboard showing transactions and balances of their multisig on the Optimism network. Financial health indicators are present through the $TEC Common and Reserve Pool Balances. The dashboard includes TEC ABC Attributes, specifically focusing on Mint and Burn Tributes paid in rETH. Lastly, it provides data on $TEC token trades, offering a holistic view of the token's market activity and liquidity.

The Augmented Bonding Curve (ABC) is a Primary Automatic Market Maker (PAMM) contract that serves as the engine for the TEC economy. statement.answer:
Using our OP Retro funding, we raised $115K from the Gitcoin network to fund OP governance (and other) projects and test a novel governance mechanism for OP. Tunable Quadratic Funding (‚ÄúTQF‚Äù) engaged OP delegates and citizens in Quadratic Funding allocation decisions for funding OP ecosystem development.

We experimented with TQF in two Gitcoin rounds, demonstrating its ability to incorporate OP badgeholder and delegate preferences into QF allocations for externally-raised capital. In Spring 2024, we incorporated an OP delegate signal, as a test in amplifying OP voices. In August, we refined the OP TQF signals, which shifted normal QF distributions by $16,205 (53.8%) and focused them on 12 projects with strong ties to the OP ecosystem and its governance. 

Finally, this project demonstrated an ability to integrate OP community-driven preferences with Subject Matter Expert priorities, which we believe is a useful contribution to OP capital allocation and broader governance decisions.
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
The above work broadly benefited the Superchain by attracting token engineering projects and expertise to the ecosystem. Interestingly, many of the projects with the greatest TQF boosts also contributed specifically to OP capital allocation and broader governance capacity:

- **Pairwise (94% boost):** Governance voting dApp optimizing decision-making and RetroPGF processes.

- **GovGraph (169% boost):** Visualizes relationships between OP governance participants, enhancing transparency.

- **Superchain Innovation Research (121% boost):** Research on Superchain tokenomics and governance.

- **Breadchain Cooperative (63% boost):** PGF DAI mechanisms for community-driven funding.

- **Inverter Network (53% boost):** Token programmability stack & no-code deployment panel, lowering barriers for token systems on OP.

- **EVMcrispr (47.1% boost):** Simplifies smart contract interactions on EVM chains, making them more accessible.

In collaboration with OSO, Passport XYZ's Humanity scores were used to better understand the likelihood of real humans that were interacting with projects over the last year. The goal was to determine which projects were driving spam/bot traffic versus which projects were driving real users to the Optimism ecosystem. 

These metrics and the analysis was used in the RPGF4 voting and review process, improving the understanding and (we believe) the outcome for voters by informing which projects were driving real humans, and organic users to the collective versus which were just bringing short term bots or spam users to the network (often low value and transient).

I‚Äôm building a dashboard to visualize the total amount of grants committed, unlocked, and claimed. This allows OP stakeholders to easily track how grants are distributed, promoting greater transparency and efficiency in the grant distribution process.

The dashboard displays the total OP grants committed, unlocked, and claimed over time, along with a percentage breakdown of locked OP, unclaimed OP, and claimed OP.

name: Streamlining Retro Funding Success: Hybrid Grants Management for Optimism
description:
General Magic‚Äôs Grants Management (GM GM) team offers a hybrid grants management system combining human and digital tooling to streamline the Retro Funding application process. 

Our services help identify eligible projects, match them with the right Retro Funding round, and guide them in creating solid and Optimism-focused applications that contribute meaningfully to governance and public goods funding. Through this process, we effectively assist Optimism with capital allocation by ensuring that projects applying for Retro Funding are aligned with Optimism‚Äôs mission and demonstrate high impact, thus directing funds toward initiatives that support the broader ecosystem.

links.name: Successful Submission - Praise RPGF3
links.description:
For the RetroPGF 3 round, we successfully supported Praise in securing funding by identifying the most impactful aspects of their work and presenting them in a compelling narrative. Our team played a crucial role in finding the right angle for Praise's application, focusing on the value of on-chain attestations and their contribution to Optimism's governance.

We emphasized Praise's integration of tools like Gitcoin Passport and Regen Score, which align with Optimism‚Äôs vision for community trust and participation. Additionally, we highlighted their newly launched attestation explorer, which allows users to review community impact data, further cementing their role in Optimism Citizens' eligibility processes. The inclusion of metrics such as 100+ users, 400+ praises, and 102 Praise Optimist attestations underscored their community engagement and governance contributions, making it clear how Praise facilitates active governance participation through its data-driven reputation and rewards system. By carefully curating these elements, the application demonstrated Praise‚Äôs measurable impact and showed how their attestation feature for Optimism is pivotal to the ecosystem.

links.name: Successful Application - Giveth Web3 House RPGF3
links.description:
For RetroPGF 3, we helped Giveth Web3 House secure 49,689.64 OP by emphasizing its role as a central hub for the Optimism ecosystem. We highlighted the house‚Äôs contributions to the Developer Ecosystem, showcasing its involvement with key projects like RetroPGF, EthBarcelona 2023, and MetaCartel, as well as its support for Hermez in advancing L2 capabilities. 

Our strategy focused on the house's alignment with Optimism‚Äôs mission, particularly in fostering community-driven innovation and public goods. We highlighted measurable impact, including 500 total visitors, 200 Optimism-related visitors, and 300 accommodated guests since 2019, while also emphasizing the house‚Äôs Solar Punk ethos and its role as a collaborative space for discussions and roundtables on Optimism‚Äôs goals. The inclusion of key financial data, such as the $35,000 yearly maintenance cost and $200,000 in accommodation value, helped justify the funding request. By positioning Giveth House as an ‚ÄúOptimism think-tank,‚Äù we underscored its importance within the ecosystem, leading to the successful RetroPGF 3 outcome.

links.name: Successful Submission - Namespace Season 5 Cycle 19 Mission Request
links.description:
For the Season 5 Cycle 19 Mission Request, we played a key role in the success of Namespace by providing essential support throughout the grant application process. Our contribution began with identifying a strategic angle that aligned with the goals of Optimism's ecosystem, focusing on Namespace‚Äôs ability to supercharge ENS utility, specifically its subname management and developer toolkit offerings. In crafting the application, we emphasized how Namespace provides comprehensive tools for ENS name owners to manage and issue subnames, fostering both individual and community engagement. We also highlighted how Namespace‚Äôs technical documentation makes it easy for developers to integrate ENS subname functionality into their projects, significantly cutting down implementation time.

Our team ensured that these differentiating factors were articulated, emphasizing the project's potential for growing the Optimism ecosystem by attracting new builders and simplifying development processes. The application also detailed key metrics from testnets, showcasing Namespace‚Äôs economic impact and user engagement. This data-driven approach and the team's extensive experience with ENS demonstrated Namespace‚Äôs capacity to deliver on its promises.

links.name: Successful Application - Unitap Retro Funding 4
links.description:
For RetroPGF 4, we assisted Unitap in securing 1,540.7 OP by highlighting its critical role in simplifying the onboarding of new users into Web3 networks. Our focus was on positioning Unitap as a comprehensive solution to the challenges of user acquisition and retention in blockchain ecosystems, emphasizing its Gas Tap, Token Tap, and Prize Tap functionalities, which have been deployed on Optimism. We showcased Unitap‚Äôs innovative approach to onboarding through Sybil-resistant gas token distribution, incentivized user missions, and unique token and prize distribution systems. 

The application highlighted successful proof-of-concept collaborations, such as Glo Dollar distributing tokens and prizes via Unitap‚Äôs tools on Optimism, proving its utility for future growth in the Web3 space. Additionally, we supported the application by presenting key impact metrics, including 2,348 total transactions, 245 interactions from trusted Optimism users, and 110 average monthly active addresses, all of which demonstrated the platform‚Äôs growing adoption. By framing Unitap as a scalable, user-friendly platform that addresses the barriers to Web3 onboarding, we ensured a successful outcome in RetroPGF 4.

links.name: Successful Application - Spearbit/Cantina Retro Funding 5
links.description:
For the Retro Funding 5 round, we assisted Spearbit/Cantina with their Cantina.xyz - OP Stack Audits application. Our approach focused on crafting a comprehensive application highlighting Cantina's established expertise in providing security audits within the Optimism ecosystem, in alignment with Optimism‚Äôs goals of ensuring robust security for the OP Stack. We emphasized Cantina‚Äôs work's impact by showcasing how their security audits for critical components, such as Optimism‚Äôs EAS and cross-chain functionality, contributed to the reliability and safety of the OP Stack.

Additionally, we illustrated how their continuous monitoring and incident response services supported projects like Omni-x and Decent.xyz, ensuring secure deployment and scalability across multiple chains. In preparing the application, we ensured that Cantina's pricing model and funding history were presented, which justified the need for continued funding. By structuring the application to emphasize Cantina's value as a trusted security partner in the Optimism ecosystem, we helped secure a successful outcome in Retro Funding 5.

name: Tribuni Telegram Bot
description:
Who We Are

Tribuni was born out of the ETH Denver hackathon, spearheaded by a team of decentralized governance practitioners. Our founding members include delegates from Blockchain@USC actively participating in Optimism's governance. With expertise spanning software engineering, product design, and product management across both Web2 and crypto landscapes, our diverse team is dedicated to enhancing the delegate experience.

Our Story

Being a delegate requires constantly staying up-to-date due to the sheer volume of information that needs to be digested. Before Tribuni, we experienced firsthand the challenges of managing extensive data and keeping track of vital governance activities. To address this pain point, we engaged with a wide range of delegates from groups such as 404DAO, Brichis, PGov, Launamu, FranklinDAO, etc. Their insights and feedback inspired us to build a tool tailored specifically for delegates like them.

Our Solution

Delegates are the cornerstone of Optimism's governance system. Active and well-informed delegates lead to resilient and sound governance. However, delegates need to process a lot of information and often find it challenging to stay up-to-date. We are humans after all.

To help delegates stay active and well-informed, our team launched Tribuni‚Äîa free Telegram mini-app built exclusively for delegates. Tribuni sends quality AI-generated proposal summaries, vote reminders, and OP forum activity digests directly via Telegram. This ensures that delegates never miss a vote or an important discussion within the OP ecosystem, as long as they're connected to Telegram.

Impact

As of September 2024, Tribuni proudly supports 28 OP delegate profiles, encompassing a staggering 28,217,127 votes combined. This substantial vote power not only surpasses Optimism's 26 million quorum but also underscores Tribuni's pivotal role in the governance ecosystem. Our platform serves 38 dedicated Optimism subscribers, including influential entities like PGOV, blockchain@USC, 404DAO, PGov, Gauntlet, Tane Gov, etc who manage multiple delegate memberships. Through Tribuni, we help them analyzed 1,113 posts across 186 forum topics, ensuring they remain well-informed and proactive in decision-making. By seamlessly integrating into their workflows, Tribuni has become an indispensable tool, empowering delegates to govern more effectively and maintain the resilience of Optimism's governance structure.

organization.name: Open Source Observer
organization.description: Open Source Observer is a free analytics suite that helps the Optimism Collective measure the impact of open source software contributions on the growth of the Superchain. We provide foundational datasets and metrics models as a public good and use these to derive insights for improving Retro Funding and grant effectiveness. Our code and infrastructure are fully open source, enabling anyone to audit or fork our models. We also lead a growing data science community motivated by the vision of "impact = profit."

name: Onchain Impact Metrics for Retro Funding
description:
Open Source Observer is a public good that helps communities measure impact and improve grant effectiveness. During Retro Funding 4 (Onchain Builders), we collaborated closely with the Citizens House to develop a comprehensive suite of onchain impact metrics and power the first "metrics-based voting" experiment.

We created a first-of-its-kind data pipeline for the Superchain: not only the data but also all source code, query logic, and underlying infrastructure is publicly available for use. With data generously provided by Goldsky, we built a unified Superchain event model covering all OP Stack chains (OP Mainnet, Base, Fraxtal, Metal, Mode, and Zora). We wrote custom logic for discovering contract deployments and attributing them to specific projects per RF4 requirements. With our friends at OpenRank, Passport, and the OP Labs data team, we designed a "trusted user model", intended to identify transaction and onchain activity from high reputation users. These models provided the foundation for calculating a range of quantitative indicators to assess the contributions of onchain builders across these chains. All methodologies, data sources, and analysis tools used in developing these metrics are publicly available.

We also maintain an important community resource called OSS Directory: a public repository of Optimism projects and their associated GitHub repos, NPM packages, deployers, contracts, and other open source artifacts, with a strict schema and validation logic to ensure consistency. There are more than 500 Optimism projects in the directory, with new submissions and updates coming in every week. During the RF4 sign-up period, we received 50+ new submissions and made numerous updates to existing projects. 

The journey to arrive at a final set of onchain impact metrics was iterative and collaborative. We worked closely with the Foundation and badgeholders to discover and refine the metrics through workshops, surveys, and asynchronous feedabck. This collaboration not only provided valuable insights for Retro Funding 4 but also laid the groundwork for more sophisticated impact assessment in subsequent rounds.

In all the work leading up to the final voting, we maintained our commitment to openness and reproducibility, and wrote extensively about the process to arrive at the final set of metrics on our blog and the Optimism governance forum.

bio.text: Working on OS Observer @ Kariba Labs. Doing things with data and public goods. YC18 üçä
Bringing privacy and funk to the people

It also discusses the journey we took with the Citizens House to design, iterate, and apply the impact metrics.

links.name: Retro Funding 4: Impact Metrics, a Collective Experiment
links.description: This forum post captures many of the public conversations about the evolution of impact metrics with the Citizens House during Retro Funding 4.

links.name: Lineage graph of RF4 impact metrics
links.description: This is our dbt-generated lineage graph (best viewed on a desktop screen), which provides an audit trail of every impact metric used in RF4. At the beginning of the graph, you see our primary data sources: raw transaction/trace data from 6 OP Stack chains; third-party data from Farcaster, OpenRank, and Passport; and project-contract relationships defined in OSS Directory and the Agora sign-up interface. At the end of the graph, you a single table of metrics by project that was served to the voting interface. In the middle, you see all of the processing and transformation necessary to connect the two!

grants.details: This was a Builder Grant that helped get OSO off the ground. You can read our "hello world" and "all done" posts on the governance forum: https://gov.optimism.io/t/introducing-open-source-observer-measuring-impact-of-oss-contributions-to-the-op-superchain/7071

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

statement.answer:
OSO's infrastructure was critical to Retro Funding 4, which used "metrics-based voting" instead of the more traditional "project-based voting" interface.

Metrics-based voting had never been tried before -- let alone for hundreds of projects across various chains. The data infrastructure we built was able to respond to all of this complexity and power a successful voting experience. (The same infrastructure was also used to screen projects for eligibility and assist with open source licensing checks.)

Once the models were released, we posted an audit/bug bounty to the community. Fortunately, no issues were raised. Months later, there still have not been any. üòÖ
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
We believe our infrastructure has been most valuable for Citizens, the Foundation, and other long-term minded governance participants.

As the Superchain scales, it will become increasingly impossible for every participant to have a detailed understanding of every project or category of projects. Data is necessary not only to better leverage the time of experts and ordinary citizens but also to create a more even playing field for builders.

Badgeholders had many positive things to say about the experience, from significant time savings to trusting that the distribution would be fairer / more meritocratic.

name: Mission Request Workshop
description:
Hello I am Jesse (Jrocki), I currently serve on the Grants Council for season 6 and I am applying for Retro Funding for a smol Mission Request Workshop I hosted at the start of season 6. It should be noted that this was just one workshop held at the start of season 6.

The goal of the workshop was to take participants through the process of brainstorming ideas for mission requests, expanding on one of those ideas then begin forming it into a mission request. In short giving participants the right context and tools required for writing their own mission request to post for sponsorship.

bio.text: Superchain Contributor | ex @optimism - Contribution Manager

During the Workshop we used this Figma Board to brainstorm Mission Request ideas together. We then grouped those ideas into common themes. After the Workshop I posted the ideas generated from the Workshop on the governance forum here for the community to use:
https://gov.optimism.io/t/intent-3-mission-request-sponsorships/8405/10?u=jrocki

name: Superchain Attestation Explorer
description:
Attestation explorer for the Superchain Optimism.
Built on Ethereum Attestation Service (EAS) with a more streamlined UX and a focus on Superchain attestations.
Enhances transparency and trust for the reputation of people and projects.

The Superchain Attestation Explorer is a powerful tool designed to enhance transparency and trust within the Optimism ecosystem by allowing users to explore attestations relevant to Optimism governance. Built on the Ethereum Attestation Service (EAS), the explorer streamlines the user experience and focuses on Superchain attestations. It serves as a critical infrastructure for understanding and verifying the reputations of individuals and projects, supporting the Optimism Collective's long-term goals of decentralization, trust, and governance participation.

By providing a seamless and intuitive interface, the Superchain Attestation Explorer improves access to essential governance data, enabling Optimism citizens and delegates to participate more effectively in governance processes such as Retro Funding. The explorer aims to make the attestation data more accessible, offering new features like leaderboards, badges, and enhanced profile views to increase community engagement and improve decision-making based on verifiable reputation.

bio.text: I keep learning.

Public Goods Maxi
Founder: Giveth, General Magic, dappnode & Commons Stack
DAO Delegate: ENS, Arbitrum, Optimism & more
Will probably convince you $GIV is Good

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

statement.answer:
The Superchain Attestation Explorer provides a user-friendly and accessible way to review and verify user reputations. While existing EAS attestation explorers present raw data, the Superchain Attestation Explorer refines this by focusing on the most useful attestation services for OP governance.

Displaying key attestation data in a more digestible format allows badgeholders & delegates to evaluate contributions and trustworthiness within the ecosystem efficiently, enhancing decision-making during critical governance processes like RetroFunding.

Praise Discord Bot
Regen Score
Optimist
Passport Score
Praise on Farcaster
Coordinape
DeVouch
Metrics Garden

The explorer showcases these eight core attestation services, including six on OP Mainnet and two on Base. This integration across multiple chains positions the explorer as a Superchain attestation tool, reinforcing its role as an essential infrastructure.
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
The primary beneficiaries of the Superchain Attestation Explorer are governance participants involved in the Retro Funding process. Specifically, OP Citizens and delegates that rely on the tool to efficiently review user reputations and contributions within the Optimism ecosystem. 

By offering a more readable interface than raw data explorers like EAS, the Attestation Explorer helps these participants make more informed decisions during governance activities.

In addition, the tool helps Retro Funding voters better assess contributors' impact and credibility, ensuring that governance rewards are distributed based on verified, high-quality contributions. 
The broader Superchain community also benefits from easier cross-chain attestation visibility.

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

statement.answer:
We built this site in response to forum feedback, where many community members shared feeling overwhelmed by the constantly evolving nature of Optimism governance, in particular the many novel experiments around grant programs.

While rapid iteration is good for innovation (yay!), it also made it more challenging to stay up-to-date without first having to "navigate a maze of forum posts". We made it easy to access all deadlines and changes to programs in one place.

This has been well received: In the period between Oct 2023 and Sept 2024, there have been 2.9K outbound link clicks from our site to the Charmverse Grants Council page, 1.1K clicks to the Foundation Mission Requests pages on GitHub, and 605 clicks to forum posts on Retro Funding Rounds.
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
Our site has primarily been useful as a tool for supporting those involved in grants processes, including the Grants Council, Retro Funding Rounds and (Foundation) Mission Requests.

The subscribers of our newsletter where we used to share weekly updates, before then focusing primarily on the website, include employees from OP Labs, OpenZeppelin and Wakeup Labs. 

The teams behind grantee projects such as OpenZeppelin are those who likely benefited most from our overview of the current status of grant programs, upcoming deadlines, the changelog, and our grants calendar.

Without our site, they would have faced a much higher workload, having to keep track of this information across various channels (GitHub, the Grants Council Charmverse page, Forum, etc.)

organization.description: Designing incentives, protocols that meet first principles thinking and modeling tools to understand novel economies.

name: Quantitative Simulations and Analysis of RetroPGF Voting Mechanisms
description:
Badgeholder behavior is a crucial determinant of the amount of funding a project will receive in RetroPGF. In this project, we develop various models of badgeholder behavior that include real-world effects such as varying levels of expertise and laziness, and implement them in an agent-based simulator to simulate various aspects of RetroPGF voting mechanisms. The purpose of these simulations is to test aspects of voting mechanisms quantitatively. Specifically, we are interested in testing how various voting mechanisms (such as Quorum + Threshold, or Pairwise) compare along the following dimensions:  1) capital allocation efficiency, 2) robustness to COI (conflict of interest), and 3) robustness to collusion. 

Our summary findings, which are detailed in the project resources, are:
When controlling for badgeholder laziness and expertise, the pairwise voting mechanism results in a closer alignment between true project rankings and the rankings inferred by the voting mechanism.
Quorum+Threshold, across a wide range of parameters, appears more resilient to COI and collusion than Pairwise.

bio.text: Krazy about you know what ‚Ä¶

github.name: Voting Mechanism Design
github.description: This repository contains agent based simulations of badgeholders interacting with different voting mechanisms, such as pairwise and quorum+threshold.  Additionally, it contains Jupyter notebooks that utilize the agent based simulations to determine the COI and collusion performance of the different voting mechanisms.

links.name: A Quantitative Simulation of Pairwise Voting for RetroPGF
links.description:
This blog post details how we used the voting_mechanism_design software to assess the performance of the pairwise voting mechanism.  The effectiveness of the mechanism and discovering the true project rankings, conflict of interest (COI) and collusion performance are all discussed for the pairwise voting mechanism. 

We find pairwise voting may be more efficient at allocating capital to impactful projects than the Quorum+Threshold mechanism, irrespective of badgeholder laziness and expertise.  

Impact:
- X statistics:  
    - 5000 views - https://x.com/Filecoin/status/1830573340513165484 
    - 380 views - https://x.com/cryptoeconlab/status/1826290227717046411 
- Posted on Medium, received 65 views and 33 reads.
- Presented at regenlearnings.xyz meeting in September, video recording here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BYrJb5KmRiI

links.name: The robustness of Quorum+Threshold Voting Mechanism to Conflicts of Interest in RetroPGF
links.description:
In this article, we assess the robustness of the Quorum+Threshold voting mechanism to COI voting behavior, and compare it to Pairwise voting.  We outline an approach to quantitatively measuring this, and explain experiments and results.  

We find that Q+T voting exhibits more robustness to COI than Pairwise, in our models of badgeholder behavior for each voting mechanism.  However, this and the previous analysis indicate that there are several dimensions to assess a voting mechanism.  Capital allocation efficiency, robustness to negative behaviors, and other factors all play a role. 

Impact:
- Posted on Medium, received 15 views and 6 reads as of Sat Oct 12.
- 146 Views on Twitter.

grants.details: This grant commissioned three different teams to investigate different aspects of the robustness of voting mechanism designs. Our team focused on using a simulation based approach to assess the robustness of different voting mechanisms to COI and collusion.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

statement.answer: Our work specifically focused on assessing the robustness of voting mechanisms, which are a central aspect of Optimism's PGF efforts. The robustness of these mechanisms to conflict of interest and collusion were not quantitatively assessed previously, and therefore, it was not previously known how well the voting mechanism that we used would far in light of negative behaviors.  Our work sheds light on this, and elucidates the tradeoffs that need to be taken into account when deciding which voting mechanism to use when designing an RPG round.
statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer: The optimism ecosystem, and specifically, the round organizers and designers of PGF funding efforts  will benefit from this infrastructure and tooling. The recommendations provided in the articles surrounding the quantitative simulations as well as the developed simulation codebase can enable round organizers to choose both the correct voting mechanism as well as the appropriate parameters to achieve the desired tradeoff between voting mechanism efficiency and robustness to negative behaviors.
statement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?

name: Curia OP Governance Analytics Dashboard
description:
We are the team behind the Curia OP Governance Analytics Dashboard, a comprehensive tool designed to empower the Optimism Collective through transparency and data-driven insights. Our dashboard provides essential governance metrics such as participation rates, voting power distribution, delegates' performance, and voting history. By continuously refining our features based on community feedback, we've enriched stakeholder engagement and informed decision-making processes.

Since last year, we've introduced significant enhancements to the dashboard, including:

Citizen House Integration: We now provide comprehensive data visualization tools for the Citizen House, focusing on Badgeholder analytics and veto proposals. This update enables a clearer understanding of activities within the Citizen House and enhances transparency around proposal results and participation.

RetroPGF Project Analytics: Our dashboard now offers detailed tracking and insights into RetroPGF projects, including an Application Funnel Overview that displays the entire project application process, from submission to decision. We also provide analytics on ongoing and upcoming RetroPGF projects, including RetroPGF 3 & 4, ensuring that the community can better understand and monitor project dynamics and impact.

UI and User Experience Improvements: We revamped the user interface, enhancing the visibility of delegate voting power and improving the navigation bar for easier interaction. Our new delegate card feature allows for more detailed and interactive insights, making it easier for users to track individual delegate activity.

Partial Delegation Integration: We introduced detailed insights into the sources of a delegate's voting power, distinguishing between partial and full delegations. This feature provides a more granular view of each delegate‚Äôs influence within the governance process.

Delegate Ranking Bump Chart: A dynamic tool that visualizes the evolution of delegates‚Äô voting power over various timeframes, offering a detailed view of ranking changes to better understand the governance dynamics.

Through these updates, the Curia OP Governance Analytics Dashboard has continued to foster a culture of accountability, transparency, and informed governance across the Optimism Collective, empowering stakeholders to make astute, data-driven decisions.

statement.answer:

statement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

statement.answer:
There are two main governance participants who have benefited from OPdelegate.com:

Delegates: Having up-to-date data on how your delegation is changing over time has been invaluable to delegates who are trying to grow their delegations. In addition, having detailed breakdowns of the size of their delegators and a list of the delegators enables them to reach out to their delegations.

Researchers/Delegators: Our dashboards provides transparency into the nature of a delegates voting power. How many delegators does a delegate have? How concentrated is their voting power? These are the types of questions that researchers have answered with our dashboards. For example, there are some delegates with 95% of their voting power coming from one wallet, and others with no more than 2% coming from their biggest delegator. Opdelegate.com makes this information accessible to everyone.

statement.answer:
The Security Council carried out its role of signing protocol upgrades approved by the Token House in accordance with the Internal Operating Procedures set out by the Security Council. 

In Season 6 the Optimism Security Council progressed from Phase 0 to Phase 1, as part of this upgrade the owner of the L2ProxyAdmin contract was reassigned from the Foundation to the Security Council.

As part of Phase 1, the signing threshold for the Security Council was increased from 4 to 10. Throughout Season 6, the Security Council continued it's streak of meeting quorum on all signing ceremonies. 

As part of Phase 1, the role of Guardian was reassigned from the Foundation to a new Guardian Safe with the Security Council Safe as its sole owner, moving Optimism closer to satisfying the 1 week exit window required for Stage 1.

name: Farcaster Attestation
description:
Farcaster Attestation is bringing Farcaster wallet verification on-chain to the Optimism Mainnet. Traditionally, Farcaster wallet verification data is only accessible through the Farcaster Hub, which cannot be utilized directly on Optimism Mainnet via Solidity smart contracts. This creates a centralization issue in the Retro Funding EAS schema, limiting the authorized attester to a single wallet, as it requires verification from a centralized backend.

Farcaster Attestation resolves this centralization problem by enabling anyone to attest their Farcaster data permissionlessly.

We have replicated the Retro Funding Project and Metadata Schema to test the integration with Farcaster Attestation. For more information, refer to the Links section.

statement.answer: Did you know that the Retro Funding application process is currently centralized and relies on trust in the application UI provider (Agora)? This is because there is no way to verify the relationship between a wallet address and a Farcaster ID on-chain. Farcaster Attestation solves this by enabling the verification of wallet addresses and Farcaster IDs on Optimism Mainnet, making the Retro Funding application process decentralized and permissionless.

Governance tooling builders gain from the permissionless Retro Funding EAS Schema, powered by Farcaster Attestation, as it allows anyone to build project management and application UIs for Retro Funding, not just Agora.

This opens the door to many creative ideas in the Retro Funding space.

name: growthepie ü•ßüìè RetroPGF 3 tracker - Clarity for Badgeholders and Project Owners
description:
For RetroPGF round 3 we developed a detailed tracker that badgeholders and projects alike used to track their current appearance in ballots, lists by badgeholders and other data. Badgeholders could speed up their voting process and have live-data (every few minutes) how project's ballots have changed. Also how much funding projects had previously received in terms of previous retroactive funding, VC funding and own token issuance.

After seeing ongoing discussions on social media around the difficulty of assessing 643 projects by badgeholders, we were addressing major issues like:

- better overview of projects in one list, if they already appear in ballots or lists (made them more visible) and what their median valuation in badgeholder's lists currently is
- detailed overview of funding reported in their application, plus gathering additional information on outside funding like VC funding, if there is a token of the project, which we made transparent in the tracker. 
- Projects could see if they made the minimum threshold.
- Everyone could have a complete overview of projects that had applied, search ability and a better way to sort projects by different variables in our list.
- Link directly to a project on Agora to see the full description allowed for faster navigation. Critical when needing to assess more than 600 projects in a few weeks.

Throughout the voting period, a huge amount of badgeholders and project's representatives used our page and the tracker (topping >1500 users per day) to see what's new. 

Feedback we have received (summarized):
- People appreciated the list view and completeness of data in a transparent and condensed view.
- Live updates made it possible to see unknown projects better.
- Some even said that our tracker transformed the whole round into a prediction market through it's live updates and badgeholder's possibility to adjust their ballot throughout.

After the voting period people were keen on seeing their result, finding our tracker to see how much they had been allocated. 

On top, throughout the whole time, our tracker has been shared many times by everyone involved in RPGF on socials and diverse platforms, which brought a lot of attention to Optimism and its retrofunding. 

This particular project (i.e. the tracker) has not received any funding from Optimism or any other source.

statement.answer:
Our analytics work for Optimism Governance was focused on RPGF3's round:

1. **Project Visibility and Ballot Tracking**: We tracked how projects appeared in badgeholders' ballots and lists, providing real-time updates on their placement and the median valuation by badgeholders.
   
2. **Funding Overview**: We analyzed and displayed the funding history of projects, including previous RetroPGF allocations, external VC funding, and token issuance. This helps assess a project's overall financial backing and need for additional support or unaccounted rewards. We also showed results.
   
3. **Voting Dynamics**: By measuring how projects move in and out of ballots over time, we offered insights into badgeholders' voting behavior and project performance throughout the voting period.

4. **User Engagement**: We tracked platform usage, monitoring the number of badgeholders and project representatives actively using the tracker, giving insights into overall engagement with the governance process.
statement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?

statement.answer:
growthepie's Optimism RPGF3 tracker helped the RetroPGF3 voting process by providing badgeholders and projects with real-time insights into project ballots, funding history, and current standings of allocations and lists, including median allocated amounts to projects. The tracker significantly streamlined decision-making and overview of users, allowing badgeholders to quickly assess 643 projects with live updates and comprehensive data. 

For Badgeholders, it enhanced transparency by offering detailed funding breakdowns, visibility of outside investments, and easy access to project descriptions on Agora. 

For project owners, they could track and promote their projects accordingly on socials or elsewhere seeing their current standing.
